DIV1.HEAD:
The Legend or Life of St. Alexius,
IN FOUR VERSIONS, FROM SIX MANUSCRIPTS.

LIST.ITEM: The longest version, in 12-line stanzas, from Laud MS. 622, in the Bodleian.
The shortest version, in couplets, from the Cotton MS., Titus A xxvi, in the British Museum.
The shorter 6-line-stanza version, from the grand Vernon MS. (ab. 1400 A.D.) and Laud 108, both in the Bodleian.
The longer 6-line-stanza version, from Laud MS. 463 in the Bodleian, and Trin. Coll. MS. Oxford 57 [81].

ARGUMENT.P: [THE first following version of the Life of St Alexius, from Laud 622, is the longest—and latest, no doubtThere is a MS. of the Life in the Durham Cathedral Library, but my enquiries about it have not yet elicited any answer.,—of the English forms of the story. It was unknown to Dr Horstmann when he edited his Altenglische Legenden; and he having calld my attention to the other three versions of the Alexius legend, I have, for completeness' sake, added them here. I have also printed the Laud 108 opposite the Vernon text, from which it differs slightly sometimes in words, and in more distinctly Midland forms (waster, was there, l. 10; hauest tou, l. 490; and tou, l. 496; and te, l. 547; some a forms, like gan, l. 168), for convenience of comparison of two later repre|sentatives of one unknown original. I should perhaps apologize for wasting so much space on a mere legend of a so-calld saint's life. But the present story is the same pathetic one as Guy of Warwick's; it is prettily versified; and the comparing of the four ways in which the same incidents are told, has a certain interest: one likes to see how the religious-story writers of old spun out or shortend their materialNote how the shorter versions lengthen the end of the story.: and the oddness of their notions as to the line of his images' life that pleasd the God and Father of men, is always in|structive, specially when set beside many of the popular ideas on this and like subjects now. If folk would but stop attributing to God, motives, opinions, arrangements and likings, which they'd con|sider an insult to set down to any wise and good friend of their own, how much useless bother would come to an end!

Dr Horstmann,—who edited the Laud 108 Life in Herrig's Archiv, vol. iii. p. 102-10, 1873I believe that he has since edited the Vernon, Trinity and Laud-463 texts.—says that the sources of the Alexius legend are the 'Vita metrica, auctore Marbodo, primum archidiacono Andegavensi, deinde Redonensi episcopo († 1123)', printed in the Acta Sanctorum, Boll. 17. Juli, p. 254-256; and another 'Vita, auctore anonymo', ib. p. 251-254. To the last, the Laud 108 version is nearly related, often even in words. Eight Middle High German versions of this Legend were edited by Mass|mann, Quedlinburg, 1843. The following Early English lives do not belong to the great Collection of long-line "Saints' Lives" in the Harleian, Vernon, and other MSS, from which I printed a selec|tionAnd mistakingly printed 'ic' as Midland or Northern 'ic', instead of the Southern 'ich'. for the Philological Society in 1863 for its Transactions, of 1858. This Collection will be edited in a separate volume some day for the E. E. Text Society, by Dr Horstmann, after he has edited for us all the Extra Legends not in the Collection or in the Vernon Gospel-stories.]

DIV1.HEAD:
THE LEGEND OR LIFE OF ST. ALEXIUS.
FROM SIX MANUSCRIPTS.

LG.L: ALle þat willen here in ryme
Hou gode Men in olde tyme
Loueden god almiȝth,
þat weren riche of grete valoure,
Kynges sones and Emperoure,
Of bodies stronge & liȝth:
ȝee habbeþ yherd ofte in geste
Of holy men maken feste
Boþe daye & niȝth,
fforto haue þe ioye in heuene
wiþ Aungels song & mery steuene,
þere blis is brode & briȝth.
¶ To ȝou alle, heiȝe & lowe,
þe riȝth soþe to biknowe
ȝoure soules forto saue,
þe self waye þat god ȝede
To folowe hym I wolde ȝou rede,
heuene forto craue;
And so duden þapostles alle,
þat to Iesu wolden calle,
ffor nouȝth þai nolde bilaue,
And to penaunce þai hem took,
werldes wele þai al forsook
Oure lordes loue to haue
¶ þise oþere holy seintz & gode,
Martirs, virgines mylde of mode,
And þise confessoures,
Religious þat her lijf willen diȝth,
fforto seruen god almiȝth
By tides & by houres;
ȝee haue yherd saide wel ofte
Man may nouȝth lede lijf to softe,
And wonen in heuene boures.
þe godspel seiþ we moten lete
werldes lijf, þat þinkeþ vs swete,
And suffren hard shoures,
¶ ffader & moder & werldes goode,
And folowe hym þat dyed on rode
ffor oure synnes sake;
And þan shullen we haue his loue,
And ioye & blis wiþ hym a-boue
þat he for vs gan make.
I shal ȝou now telle wiþ mouþe
Of on þat is name couþe
þat suffred woo & wrake.
his holy lijf & his godenesse
I may tellen more & lesse,
In woo hou he gan wake.
¶ he forsook confort of al his kynde,
Richesse he lete al bihynde,
To god al he hym took:
Alexius is his name in storie,
writen of whom is made memorie
In many holy book.
In Rome, þat was noble Cite,
woned a Man of grete pouste,
þat mychel mirþe a[MS. of a] wook;
his lijf he lad worschiplich,
honoured he was of pouere & riche
þat on hym gan look.
¶ Eufeniens was his name;
Of godenesse was his fame
In þe Cite of Rome.
þerfore þe riche Emperoure
Of þe Cite made hym Cenatoure.
ffor loos of his wisdome.
Riche he was of grete honoures,
Of londes, Castels, & of toures;
Men speken of hym ylome
In alle þinges wiþouten strijf;
Vche man he tauȝtte holy lijf
To his court þat come.
¶ Stronge he was in armes & liȝth,
Aȝeins Erle, baroun, & kniȝth,
his lordes riȝth to defende;
þerfore hym loued þe Emperoure,
And made hym maister & gouern|oure
Of his tresore to spende.
To his somouns in armes clers
Two þousandes he had of bachelers,
þat curteis weren & hende,
And alle yshred in cloþes of golde,
None fairer miȝtten ben on molde,
In þe werldes ende.
¶ Men þat ȝeden in pilerinage
And Men of ordre[MS. oydre], was his vsage
Often forto fede.
Dame Agloes hiȝth his spouse,
Her dedes weren wel preciouse
Holy lijf to lede.
She was fair honeste & wijs,
Louelich, & of gret prijs,
Ycome of gode kynrede;
Aȝeins no Man she mystook,
wiþ contenaunce ne wiþ look,
Noiþer in word ne dede.
¶ Barayne was þat gode wijf,
In sorouȝ she ledde her lijf,
ffor she no childe hadde.
hir lorde for þat ilk þinge
Ofte his honden gan to wrynge,
And sorouȝful lijf he ladde;
ffor he wende þat god almiȝth
had ben wrooþ wiþ hym apliȝth,
þereof sore hym dradde.
Ofte he bisouȝth god in heuene
Sende hem a childe, wiþ mylde steuene,
To maken hem bliþe & gladde,
¶ Conforte of hym forto haue,
her godes after hem to saue,
her londes & her ledes;
her eyre of hym forto make,
And her richesse hym bitake,
Palfreies & her stedes.
Ofte þai maden þus her bone,
And god sent hem grace sone,
þat fulfilde were þoo dedes:
A son conceyued þat gode wijf;
Tyme com in her olde lijf
ybore it most be nedes
¶ þai þankeden god, & glade were,
And avoweden in þis manere
Chastite boþe to take,
And to lyuen in clene lijf,
Eufeniens & his gode wijf,
And synne to forsake.
þe childe was mery in al manere,
As þai maden her praiere,
Aniȝth as þai gan wake.
Alexius þai gonnen hym calle;
yloued he was amonges hem alle
þat to hym gonnen take.
¶ Alexius was sett to boke,
To gode maistres þai hym toke,
And wise of clergie.
þe more he wex in elde & lengþe,
To seruen god he dude his strengþe
And his moder Marie.
To þe Emperour whan he was brouȝth
þere dedes of Armes weren ywrouȝth
To lernen chiualrye;
þere miȝth he sen in tour[na]ment
what kniȝth was douȝttiest of dent
And man of most maistrie.
¶ His fader was boþe wijs & ware,
ffor þat his son so wel hym bare,
he loued hym al his lijf.
he þouȝth to don swiche puruyaunce,
whar-wiþ he miȝth hym avaunce
And wynne hym a wijf.
To a riche prince his son he sent,
And afterward to hym he went,
Stille wiþouten strijf:
A douȝtter he had, briȝth & shene,
þe heritage shulde hires bene
Of Castel & londes rijf.
¶ whan ayþer herd oþeres wille,
And speken þerof to-gedre stille
To make þat sposaile,
Of þe tyme comen was þe day
To fulfille wiþouten delay,
Certeyn, wiþouten faile,
To þe chirche of seint Bonefas
wiþ þis maiden þai token þe pas,
þat heiȝe was of paraile;
As custume was & shulde be,
þai maden gret solempnite,
þe Pope & his conseile.
¶ Alexius was shamefast,
And of weddyng he was agast,
his vijs al pale bywent;
Leuer hym were to be ded
þan haue ytrowed þat ilk red
By his owen assent.
He ne wist what he miȝth don;
fful gret sorouȝ com hym on,
he helde hym-self shent.
To god he gan hym al affye,
And to his moder seint Marie,
Trewely, wiþ gode entent.
¶ Naþeles he lete his heuynysse,
And made mychel ioye & blisse
At þat solempnite.
He bare hym curteislich & tsllie,
To fulfille his faders wille,
Glad as he had ybe.
ffulfild was þe weddyng
wiþ ioye & blis in al þing,
þat many man miȝth see.
þe niȝth was comen, & þe day gon,
þe kniȝttes waten on & on
To her owen cuntre.
¶ Eufeniens his son gan calle,
And tidynges amonge hem alle
He tolde hym þat were newe.
'Son, to þi chaumbre þou most wende,
To þi wijf fair & hende,
Blysful & briȝth of hewe.'
And whan Alixius herd þat word
It pricked his hert as speres oord,
So sore it gan hym rewe;
Bot his fader wraþþi he nolde,
He had leuer be vnder molde,
þat neuer man hym knewe.
¶ whan þe folk was went away,
And he al-one in chaumbre lay,
Alexius gan to preche;
Of Iesu he bigan his game,
werldes likyng he gan blame,
his ȝonge wijf to teche.
He tauȝtte hir, þat was so hende,
Hou she shulde haue god to frende
þat is oure soules leche;
ȝif she wolde alle her lijf
Duelle boþe maiden & wijf,
þe fende she miȝth do wreche.
¶ þat maiden herkned swiþe stille,
And whan he seide had al his wille
þe holy gost hir lauȝtte,
And she hym graunted wiþ mylde mood
To louen Iesu þat dyed [on] rood,
As he hym-self hir tauȝtte.
Alexius was þoo glad & bliþe,
his ioye couþe he noman kiþe;
his spouse a ryng he rauȝtte,
And seide to hir, 'my suete þing,
Take to þee þis ilk ryng,
And kepe it in þine auȝtte.
¶ 'Of me whan þou wilt haue mynde
Loke here-on, as þou art hende,
Boþe by day & niȝth.
In pilerynage now wil I go,
And half þe godenesse þat I do
Graunte þee god almiȝth.'
Alexius þus his leue tooke;
Rewely his wijf gan on hym loke
þat was so fair &[MS. w] briȝth;
She ne wist to what londe
þat she miȝth sende hym any sonde,
Doune fel þat swete wiȝth.
¶ Alixius from his richesse
In-to pouert & wrecchednesse,
ffrom his frendes he fledde.
vnto þe Cee he com wel sory,
A shippe he fonde to seil redy,
þe holy gost hym ledde.
Of his golde & of his pens
wel he aquited his despens,
hendely of þat he hedde.
þe wynde aroos at her wille,
wheþer þai wolde, loude or stille;
At her likyng þai spedde.
¶ At a Cite Galys men calle
To londe þai gonnen aryuen alle,
wiþouten enpeirement.
Alexius of hem took leue,
And worschiplich þai hym ȝeue:
To chircheward he went.
He þanked god wiþ good wille
Erly & late, loude & stille,
þat þider hem hadde sent.
He bisouȝth god, & gan to wepe,
þat from þe fende he shulde hym kepe
And his enticement.
¶ þus he þat had riche wedes,
Heiȝe hors, & gode stedes,
And Armes briȝth & shene,
Al he leet þe godes gret,
And went on his bare feet,
his soule to make clene.
Ofte it fel in his mende
Of his fader & moder hende,
þat souȝth he schulde bene.
He wolde for none kynnes þing
þat Men hadden of hym knouyng,
þerfore he gan to flene.
¶ ffrom þat cuntre swiþe he ȝede,
To-ward Surrie in feble wede,
þat noman shulde hym knowe.
þere he duelled in grete pouerte,
In hunger, in þorst, & oþer smerte,
þat many man it sowe.
þe Cee of grece passed he is,
In-to þe Cite of Annys,
He com þat ilk þrowe.
God he bitauȝtte his compaignye,
And ȝede to a chirche of seint Marie
wiþ herte meke and lowe.
¶ At þat chirche is an ymage
Of oure lefdy vpon a stage,
þat many man haþ souȝth.
It was ymaked of Aungels honde,
To def & doumbe of oþere londe
Miracle þere was wrouȝth.
Alexius was glad & bliþe,
His ioye couþe he noman kiþe,
In hert ne in þouȝth,
whan he miȝth seen in signe
Hou goddes ymage fair & digne
In his moders barme was brouȝth.
¶ Often he made his orisoune,
wepande wiþ deuocioune,
To þe quene of heuene,
And seide, 'moder mylde & free,
Praie þi son of gret pouste
ffor his names seuene,
þat from heuene com to þee,
By assent of þe trinite,
þorouȝ þe Aungels steuene,
Here to suffre many peynes
In al his body & his veynes,
In erþe as I can neuene,
¶ 'And þat he sheweþ in his mercy,
Marie, to þee I make my cry,
þat am a synful Man;
ffor wiþ his blood & peynes grene,
þe whiche to vs purchaced ene,
ffro helle he vs wan.
Swete Iesu, heuene sire,
warisshed he is þat wil þe desire
ffrom þe fende sathan.
wel is hym þat suffren may
ffor þi loue niȝth oiþere day,
Peyne þat paie þee can.'
¶ whan noþing nas hym bileued,
And he fer from his frendes to dreued,
his cloþes weren to rent.
Amonge þe pouere in þe chirche hawȝe
he begged, & was her felawȝe,
And took þat god hym sent.
Almesse þat god hym ȝeue,
þe pouer þat wolde þere bileue
wiþ hym in present,
He ȝaf þat haluendel & more,
And was hym-self of hungred sore,
And took it in good entent.
¶ Euery sonenday houseled he was,
And shryuen also of vche trespas
þat fel to any synne.
Michel he waked & litel he sleep,
Of þat he shulde his body wiþ kepe,
Litel hym com wiþinne.
ffrom þe tyme he took his tourne
ffrom Rome, þere he was borne,
he was souȝth of his kynne
In alle cuntrees, in euery toun,
In chirche, in felde, vp & doun,
ffor nouȝth wolde þai blynne.
¶ His kynrede com þere hym biside,
þat had ysouȝth hym fer & wide,
& ȝaf hym her Almesse,
As he sat amonge þe pouere,
In grete meschief & stronge to couere,
ffor hunger in wrecchednesse.
Sore of hym þai gonnen rewe,
Stille he satt, & wel hem knewe,
Her names more & lesse.
Ychaunged was his faire hewe
þorouȝ reyn & wynde þat on hym blewe,
And oþer stronge destresse.
¶ whan þai miȝtten nouȝth spede,
Ne hym of axen in no þede
Ne in no londe of take,
wiþ sorouȝ þai gradde, allas! allas!
And wenten to Rome, þe riȝth pas,
her sorouȝ miȝth nouȝth slake.
Alexius noþing þouȝth,
Bot on Iesu crist he þouȝth,
And grete ioye he gan make
ffor he ne was nouȝth biknowe
Of his frendes heiȝe ne lowe,
His welþe gan a-wake.
¶ Eufeniens seide in his mende,
'þe most wrecche fer oiþere hende
Certes now am I.
Conforte ne ioye ne may me come;
Now my childe is me bynome
My song is tourned to cry.
My wijf is barayne, & ek olde;
She ne may haue no childe for colde,
Oure heir al forto by.
In sorouȝ & care my lijf is diȝth,
ffor to dye it were my riȝth,
And hennes to party.'
¶ wiþ þat his moder fel to grounde
And lay yswowen a longe stounde,
And roos vp al afrayed:
'My leue son, þat were so meke,
I ne woot where I shal þee seke,
þerefore I am dismayed.'
His moder ne miȝth lete sorouȝ,
Neiþer at euene ne at morowe,
In sawȝe as it is seide.
To hir chaumbre she went in hast,
And of hire bedd þe cloþes doun cast,
And siþen hem al to breyde,—
¶ Ciclatounes þat weren of prijs,
Pelured wiþ Ermyne & wiþ grijs,
Alle she cast away,
And wered cloþes symple & blake.
Litel she sleep, & mychel gan wake,
And fasted euery daye.
'Lorde,' she seide, 'almiȝtty,
To þee & to þi moder mary
I make a vow, & saye,
þat I shal neuer hennes wende
Tyl Alexius come oiþer sende,
Oiþer I be roted in clay.'
¶ Now mowen ȝee here pleynt pitouse
Of Alexius trewe spouse,
Hou she made her mone;
In gret sorouȝ was hir entent,
Her here she drouȝ, her cloþes rent,
Grymly she gan grone.
'Al my ȝouþe & my solas,
Myne hope, is lorne, allas,
And my bidyng alone.
I. am boþe maiden & wijf,
I. noot to whom telle my strijf,
I lyue as ankre in stone.
¶ 'Siþþe I ne haue to whom me mene,
Lijk is my lijf on to sene—
þat am wiþouten red—
þe turtel þat is for sorouȝ lene,
And tredeþ on no gras grene,
Siþen hire make is ded.
Allas, hou shal I. ioye haue?
Oiþer hou shal I my-seluen saue
To lyue in maidenhede?
Me were leuer of hym a siȝth,
þan welde al þis londe riȝth
In lengþe & in brede.'
¶ She roos vp erlich a morowe,
And to his moder she went in sorouȝ
ffor loue of hire spouse,
And praied hir þat she most duelle
wiþ hir, þat sorouȝful pleynt to telle,
þat strong was and greuouse.
þe lefdy was wel apaied
whan she had þus yseied,
þat was so preciouse.
And at oo bed & oo cloþing,
Seuentene ȝer was her duellyng
Boþe in one house.
¶ Lordynges, ȝee þat willeþ lere,
a faire miracle ȝee mowen here:
Bifore þat self ymage,
þere þat Alexius sate
wiþ pouere men in þe gate
As a pouere page,
þe ymage, þat aungels gonne wirche,
Spaak to þe serieauntz of þe chirche
þere she stood on þe stage,
And hete hem alle wiþouten lettynge
Goddes sergeaunt to chirche brynge
wiþouten any outrage.
¶ 'He is riȝth stedfast of lijf;
His werkes shullen ben made rijf
Ouer al fer & neere.
þe holy gost wiþinne hym rest;
Charite sitteþ in his breest,
Brennande as fyre.
Longe in pouerte his lijf he haþ led;
He ne com neuere in no bed
þise seuentene ȝere;
His holy lijf, bot god alone,
Ne woot non in þis werldes wone;
To seintȝ he may be pere.'
¶ þe sergeauntz lepen out in hast,
As men þat weren sore agast,
And ful of grete drede
Of þe ymage þat to hem spak
Of goddes sergeaunt wiþouten lak
þat sat in beggers wede.
wyde aboute þai hym souȝth,
And ȝut founden þai hym nouȝth
Amonge þe pouere felawrede;
And whan þai nouȝth hym fynde miȝth,
To þat ymage onon riȝth
Hastilich þai ȝede,
¶ To þat Maryole wiþ teres clere,
And bisouȝth hir on þis manere,
'þat she sent hem grace
Goddes man hou þai shulden knowe,
þat had ben heiȝe & bare hym lowe,
And where he sat in place.'
þe ymage spaak ofte wordes newe,
'I ȝou hote, sergeauntȝ trewe,
Aȝein[ward] þat ȝee pace;
Amonge þe pouere he sitteþ, to-tore
Boþe bihynde & bifore,
wiþ a lene face.'
¶ þe sergeauntȝ stirten out skeet,
þai founden hym, & kisten his feet,
And mercy þai hym cryde,
And ledden hym in-to holy chirche,
Goddes werkes forto wirche,
þereinne to abide.
Of þe gode mannes loos
þe miracle & þe cry aroos
Ouere al in vche syde;
Michel poeple þider ran,
Of þe miracles þat herden þan,
Of cuntrees fer & wyde;
¶ And worschiped hym in word & dede,
Alle þat miȝtten in lengþe & brede;
And duden hym gret honoure,
And beden hym, boþe day & niȝth,
He bere her erande to god almiȝth
þat is oure saueoure.
þo was Alexius swiþe woo
ffor þat he was honoured soo,
And made grete doloure;
For swiche honoure & swiche glorie,
As it is writen in his storye,
He ne loued in toun ne toure.
¶ ffor þat his meryte wolde slake
þat he shulde of god take,
þerfore it liked hym ille.
werldes honoure forto flee,
Al by niȝth, in pryuete,
He stale away ful stille
In-to þe londe of Galys.
To seint Iames chirche I-wys
he com wiþ gode wille,
And þere he sete amonge pouere men,
And beged his mete in þe fen,
his penaunce to fulfille.
¶ þoo he had þere twelfmonþe ysete
wiþ pouere Men, & begged his mete,
His fadres sergeauntȝ come
And souȝtten hym forsoþe I-wys
In pilerynage at Galys,
To bryngen hym to Rome.
And whan Alexius hem gan see,
Stillelich he gan flee,
As man of riȝt wisdome:
In-to thars he þouȝth fare,
And at þe Royn he fonde ȝare
A shippe þat was al tome,
¶ And Pilgrymes gret plente
þat wolden passen ouer þe Cee,
To tars þat wolden ȝare.
He bad þe shipman, for goddes loue
þat is in heuene vs aboue,
he most wiþ hem fare.
Grete grucchyng þai alle made;
Alexius fer & ner gan wade,
ffor nouȝth wolde he spare;
Euere he cried loude & shille,
Til þai graunted hym his wille,
þoo was he out of care.
¶ þai drowen vp seil, þe wynde was good,
And saileden ouer þe salt flood,
þe weder was at her wille;
vntil, þe þrid dayes ende,
Swiche a storme Iesus gan sende,
þat alle hem liked ille.
þai wenden wel haue went to tars;
þe wynde was gret, & noþing skars,
þonder dyned shille;
ffor liȝttynges grete, & þonder blast,
wel sore þe poeple was agast,
þai grete & groned grille.
¶ þe wynde hem droof, forsoþe to seyne,
In-to þe londe of Romeyne,
þere Alexius was borne;
þoo was þe poeple in wel more care,
ffor þat þai were aryued þare,
þan þai weren er biforne;
ffor þat tyme were þe folk of Rome
þe mest shrewen of cristendome
wiþouten oþes ysworne.
ffor pilgrymes þat aryueden þere,
her catel þat þai wiþ hem bere,
On hast was forlorne.
¶ Riȝth so bifel by þoo dawes
By Alexius & his felawes.
Of sorouȝ was her speche;
Also sumtyme bifel a cas,
þoo god almiȝtty bad Ionas
To Nyniue gon & preche;
Ionas wist wel her wille,
þe folk of niniue weren ille
And wicked for to teche;
Away Ionas wolde haue ystole
ffrom goddes hest, & han hym hole;
Ak sone hym fel a wreche.
¶ Ionas wende god bigile,
And wolde haue went to anoþer yle
In þe grikkissh Cee;
he gan to shippen atte Ryuage;
wynde aroos wiþ wood rage,
þat sorouȝ it was to see.
ffyue dayes euere iliche it lest
wiþ sorouȝ & care, her tempest,
þat seyl ne miȝth þere be.
þan seide þe maister 'forsoþe Iwys
Sum cursed Man amonges vs is,
þat wel witen mowe we.
¶ 'we willeþ caste amonges vs alle,
Lott, on whom it may bifalle,
And ouere bord he shal be cast.'
And whan þe prophete herde þis,
He þouȝth he had ydon amys,
And was sore agast.
þries þai beren aboute þat lot,
Ac on Ionas fel vche grot,
þe first and þe last.
þe maister hym þrew ouere bord;
A whal hym swalewe at oo word
ffor oo morsel in hast;
¶ And þere he dwelled forsoþe apliȝth
þre dayes fulle & þre niȝth,
ffor Ionas was vntrewe;
And at þe þre dayes ende,
Swiche grace god gan sende,
þe Cee to londe hym þrewe.
whan þe whal was comen to londe,
þerto was many mannes honde
On hym forto hewe;
And whan þe whal was to-cleued,
Ionas pylte vp his heued,
And gan his body shewe.
¶ vp he roos, þe folk to teche,
And goddes wordes he gan preche,
And lered hem her lefnesse,
And made hem wynne goddes loue,
To wonen wiþ hym in heuene aboue,
þe poeple more and lesse.
¶ Riȝth so Alexius had yment
To Tars forto haue ywent;
Ac god hym sent destresse,
And made hym to Rome wende,
To wonen þere among his frende,
holy wryt bereþ witnesse.
¶ whan Alexius was to londe ygon,
Seyl þai drouȝen vp onon,
And wenten in þe Cee,
Al to thars till þai come
ffro þe wicked londe of Rome,
And maden solempnite.
Alexius com in-to his owe,
And of his frendes was he nouȝth knowe,
ffor so naked was he;
And als a straunge man he went
To his fader wiþ gode entent,
And seide to hym par charite,
¶ 'Eufeniens, goddes frende,
þou art holden good & hende,
Alesed of gret Almesse!
ffor his loue þat was ybete,
And for vs suffred woundes grete,
helpe me in þis destresse,
ffor I ne can to no Man gon
Mete to crauen, bot þee on,
No herberewe more ne lesse;
Make of me þi bede-man!
And by hym þat þis werlde wan,
þou miȝth haue heuene blis;
¶ 'ȝiue me þe crommes of þi table,—
þan doostou dedes merciable,—
And herberewe in þine house;
And of Alexius, þi son so fre,
Afterward I shal telle þee,
þat þou helde preciouse:
þan shaltou be day & niȝth
Glad, whan þou hym seest wiþ siȝth,
And ek þi trewe spouse.'
Eufeniens ansuered þoo,
'I graunt wel þat it be so.
þine bedes ȝif þou wilt ouse.'
¶ To a Man he hym bitook,
þat seke Men couþe wel look,
Nouȝth as a Man of task;
To kepe þat Man he bad hym þink,
And brynge hym boþe mete & drynk
whan he wolde ask.
'ȝif god wil, my creatoure,
He shal be kepte wiþ honoure,
His peynes forto lask,
To seien his bedes, & bidde for me
To veray god in trinite,
fforto he be roted to ask.'
¶ Eufeniens bad he shulde be
þere þat he miȝth hym ysee
late and erly;
In þe halle he shulde be layd.
was þere non þat it wiþsayd,
Bot graunted hastyly;
þai loued hym more þan any man.
To kepe hym wel, he hete hem þan,
And wisten neuer why
His wijf hym loued at herte dere;
wel wolde she þat he serued were,
And mychel was hym by.
¶ wiþouten any grucchyng word,
Mete þat was vpon hire bord
þai senten hym to almesse,
Riȝth of her owen dissh,
were it flessh oiþer fissh,
while he was in destresse;
þus was þe pilegryme yserued þan.
who he was, wist noman,
Gret was his þolemodenesse;
ffor ȝif his moder oiþer his wijf
hadden ywist Alexius lijf,
It had ben her gladnesse.
¶ wiþ hym þai speken, & hym seiȝen
wiþ her mouþe & wiþ her eiȝen,
ffader & moder & wijf;
Nouȝth for þan non hym knew,
Noiþer by hide ne by hew;
Al chaunged was his lijf.
His fader he seiȝ often grete,
And his moder teres lete
ffourty siþes & fyue.
yuel miȝth hym liken þat seiȝ þis;
his martirdom was strong I-wys,
Of sorouȝ & paynes ryue.
¶ Alexius in al wise
Dude to god his seruise
wiþ stedfast wille in hert,
In fastyng, & in orisouns,
In many manere deuociouns
Of peynes þat weren smert.
And al was forto wynne heuene;
To here Aungels wiþ mylde steuene,
he suffred þis pouert
ffulle seuentene ȝer;
he wered breech maked of her,
And al swiche was his shert.
¶ Sergeauntz, þat þere-inne were,
Ofte siþes gramed hym þere,
And despised hym fast.
þe wasshyng of her vessel
þai cast on hym euerydel,
þat was swiþe vnwrast;
And cleped hym shrewe ypo|crite,
And ofte-tymes gonne hym smyte
Vnder þe cheke in hast:
Ac Alexius was of god fulfild,
In gode penaunce he it helde,
And þanked hem at þe last.
¶ Alexius, þat was goddes kniȝth,
ffor penaunce þat was on hym liȝth,
Almest his lijf was lorne.
Wel he seiȝ, þorouȝ deþes lawȝes,
þat he drouȝ to his endyng dawȝes,
ffor deþ com hym biforne.
His sergeaunt he cleped sone,
And for his loue, bad hym a bone,
þat bare þe crovne of þorne,
To fecche hym enk & parchemyne,
fforto write in latyne
His lijf siþþe he was borne.
¶ His sergeaunt was glad & bliþe;
Enk & parchemyn also swiþe
He fette, & hym bitook;
Alexius þo write bigan;
Ak þere was non bifore þan
þat wist he couþe in book.
þere-inne he wroot oord & ende,
Hou he fro his wijf gan wende,
And al his kyn forsook;
And hou Alex at his partyng,
whan he took his wijf þe ryng,
hou rewly she gan look;
¶ And hou in pilerynage he ȝede,
In hunger, in þorst, in pouere wede,
And in what manere,
And hou he sat in grete destresse
Amonge þe pouere, & fenge almesse
Seuentene ȝere;
And hou his frendes comen hym by,
And he hem knew apertely,
þat souȝtten hym fer & nere;
And hou he stale a-way hem fro,
þat non hym knew of alle þo,
So chaunged was his chere;
¶ And hou þe ymage of oure lefdy
þe sergeauntz hete apertely,
In, hym, forto take,
And byd his bedes in þe chirche,
Goddes werkes þere to wirche,
His sorouȝ forto slake;
And hou þat folk com fer & wyde
To þat chirche in vche syde,
honour hym forto make;
And hou he stale away hem fro,
And wolde nouȝth be honoured so,
bot libbe in woo & wrake;
¶ And hou he wolde to tars haue went,
And whiche a tempest god hym sent,
þat droof hem to Romeyne;
And hou he bad his fader good
herberewe & oþer lyues food,
He wroot forsoþe to seyne;
And hou he seiȝ seuentene ȝere
ffader, & moder, & wijf þere,
wiþ sorouȝ & mychel peyne;
And he wolde hem nouȝth yknowe,
Bot bare hym boþe symple & lowe,
þat had ben Man of meyne.
¶ Iesus, þat is kyng of glorie,
his martirdom & his victorie
Seiȝ, & his trauaile;
And whan he had his lijf ywrite,
he hidde þere noman shulde ywite,
his book of gode paraile.
Priuelich Alex it bare,
þat noman miȝth þerof be-ware
Hou mychel it wolde auaile;
And, whan he dyed, I vnderstonde
It was founden in his riȝth honde,
writen wiþouten faile.
¶ On palme sonenday, after messe,
In þe chirche amonge þe presse,
A voice com, I ȝou rede,
ffrom heuene adoune, wel shille & clere,
þat seide to hem in þis manere,
where-of many gonne drede,
And seide, 'ȝee þat trauailed be
In hunger & þurst for loue of me,
Comeþ! I shal ȝou fede,
In heuene, þat is so fair & briȝth,
þare euere is day & neuere niȝth,
And ioye wiþouten drede.'
¶ þe poeple & þe clergie,
ffor þat voice songen þe letanye
wiþ gode deuocioun;
And bisouȝtten þe heuene kyng,
þat he shulde ȝiue hem tokenyng
ffro heuene to erþe adoun,
Of þe voice what it were
þat among hem com þere
wiþ so mery soun.
þe voice com eft anoþer tyme,
And seide as I schal seie in Ryme;
Herkneþ þis resoun:
¶ 'þere is a Man of dedes gode,
Spirituel, & mylde of mode,
Now in Rome Cite;
In penaunce he is ȝou amonge,
Certeynly ȝee ne shullen nouȝth longe
here in erþe hym see;
A gode fridayes morowenyng
he shal wende to heuene kyng,
þat sytteþ in trinite.
Takeþ wiþ hym þe riȝth pace
To þe chirche of seint Boneface
wiþ grete solempnite.'
¶ þai souȝtten hym & nouȝth ne founde,
And hadden many sorouȝful stounde,
Til þe gode fryday;
wiþ gret deuocioun among,
Of bedes & of chirche song,
To god þai maden her pray;
þai praiden hym for his pyte,
And for his mychel humilite,
þat he hem sent to say
where was þe Man þe Aungel of tolde
Twyes er þan wiþ wordes bolde,
þat in swiche payne lay.
¶ þe þrid tyme com þe voice
ffro hym þat was don on croice
wiþ gret solempne liȝth,
And seide, 'wendeþ wiþoute soioure
To Eufeniens þe Cenatoure,
ffor þere he lijþ vche niȝth.
Swiþe good haþ ben his lijf;
His werkes shullen be made rijf;
His soule is fair & briȝth.'
þat ilk tyme, as I ȝou seie,
His gost went þe riȝth weie
ffro þe body to god almiȝth.
¶ þe holy pope Innocent
And þe Emperoures swiþe went,
Sire Eufeniens to calle,
And chalenged hym in þis manere,
Eufeniens & his wijf yfere,
Riȝth amonge hem alle;
'In þine house is, þat is so meke,
Goddes man þat we seke;
Hou may þis cas bifalle?
we haue ysouȝth hym fer & wyde,
Hou darstou goddes sergeaunt hyde
In boure oiþer in halle?'
¶ Eufeniens ansuered sone,
As he auȝtte forto done,
To þe pope Innocent,
And seide, þeiȝ he shulde deye,
Of swiche a Man couþe he nouȝth seye,
By god omnipotent[MS. omnipototent];
'ffor swiche a Man ȝif I knewe,
ffayn I wolde hym to ȝou shewe
Treuly wiþ god entent.'
þan seiden þe Cardinales twelue,
'God ȝeue þat it were þi-selue
Byfore vs in present.'
¶ In þat tyme tweie emperoures
Of Rome kepten þe honoures
wiþ her cristen menee;
þat on hete Archadius,
And þat oþere Honorius;
þai weren hende & fre.
wiþ Eufeniens þai wenten riȝth
fforto fecchen goddes kniȝth,
þat was so good of fe.
Ac eufeniens was swiþe liȝth,
And went bifore his hous to diȝth
wiþ gret solempnite
¶ Eufeniens, whan he hom cam,
Al his meignee he vndernam,
ȝif þat þai euere ysowe
Any Man þat so holy were
As þe Aungel tolde of ere,
Of his meignee to knowe.
Alexius wardeyn com þan,
And seide, 'sir, it is ȝoure bede|man,
þat lijþ ded by þe wowe;
He þat þou hast so longe yfed,
wiþ mete & drynk, clooþ &. bed,
He bare hym euer lowe.
¶ 'I trowe wel it may so be,
whom so ȝee seche, þat it is he,
ffor he was good of lijf;
His bedes he bad as a frere,
Ne wolde he nouȝth, while he was here,
Louen fiȝth ne strijf;
A book in his honde he halt
Swiþe fast, & narewe yfalt,
who þat it couþe descryue;
I ne woot what he þereinne wrouȝth;
þe parchemyn I hym bouȝth,
Gon fourty dayes & fyue.'
¶ þoo þat þis herden þe Emperoures
And oþere lordes of honoures,
þai þankeden god almiȝth.
He led hem þere lay þat body,
Clene & fair, & sumdel rody,
fface feir & briȝth.
þe on Emperoure his honde vp took,
And wolde haue taken out þe book
þat was fair of siȝth;
Alexius þe book helde þoo;
þan was þe Emperour swiþe woo,
And in his herte afliȝth.
¶ þe Emperour þoo speke bigan,
And seide vnto þe body þan,
þere it lay in þe herne;
'þouȝ we ben Men of synful lijf,
Emperours we ben wiþouten strijf,
Rome forto gouerne;
we defenden holy chirche
Aȝeins hem þat wolden wirche
Dedes stoute & sterne;
þerfore delyuer vs þi book,
þat þe poeple þere-on mowe look,
wisdom forto lerne.'
¶ whan þai hadden so yseide,
Alexius, þere he was yleide,
Opened vp his honde;
To þe pope wolde he nouȝth forsake,
Bot lete hym þoo þe book vptake,
To rede þat he fonde.
þoo þapostoile had his book,
His chaunceler he it bitook
To rede, I vnderstonde;
Othoo was his name,
A Man yholde of gode fame
Ouer al Rome londe.
¶ þe book he red wiþ gode wille,
þe folk herkned & helde hem stille
wiþouten any boost
Til þe book was red & seide.
Alexius was bifore hem leide,
ffulfild of þe holy gost.
þe chaunceler wel loude grad
whan he þe book of Alexius rad
Among þe cristen ost;
hou he fro frendes gan wende,
And hou his fader fer & hende
Souȝth hym by euery cost;
¶ And hou he was to þe Emperoure
ysent, to be Man of valoure
And lernen chiualrie,
Of huntyng, & of Ryuere,
Of chesse pleieyng & of tablere:
Al nas worþ a flye;
Leuer hym was to conne good,
And seruen god wiþ mylde mood,
and his moder Marie:
And hou he ȝede seuentene ȝer
In pilerinage fer & ner
wiþ mychel maladye;
¶ And oþer ȝeres seuentene
wiþ his fader he had ybene,
his bedeman by þe wowe,
þat fader ne moder ne his wijf
wisten of his holy lijf,
Ne þat he was hire owe;
And hou his fader sergeauntz alle,
veyn glorie gonne hym calle,
And gorre on hym gonne þrowe;
And hou he þe book ywriten hadde:
Of al his lijf, þere he it radde
To þe poeple heiȝe & lowe.
¶ þoo Eufeniens þise wordes herd,
Of his son hou it ferd,
Gret was his sorouȝeyng;
His face he[MS. his] rent, & his her.
Men sorouȝed for hym fer & ner,
He fel in swowenyng.
On his owen son þat was,
His cry was euere, 'allas! allas!
deþ! why nyltou me stynge?
Allas! sorouȝ! what is þi red?
þou hast me brouȝth vnto my ded;
Myne herte wil to-sprynge.
¶ 'Now I may no ioye haue;
No confort ne may me saue;
My blis is al forlorne!
ffor my son þat lijþ here ded,
In elde he shulde haue ben my red.
Allas! þat I was borne!
O son, whi woldestou suffren smert,
And dye wiþ me here in pouert,
A begger as þou worne?
To þi comyng was al my speire,
To haue ymade of þee myne eire,
Of londe, Castel & corne.'
¶ His moder herd þat tydynge;
ffor hir son she gan flynge
In Rage as a lyonesse;
Sorouȝ-fullich her pleynt she made;
Noman miȝth hire herte glade,
Of al þe grete presse.
His fader had ylore þe speche;
To his moder was no leche
þat miȝth her cry acesse.
Letted she nouȝth for al þe þrong,
þat she ne ran þe poeple among,
Hire son to clyppe & kysse.
¶ "O son, þat soke of myne pappes,
þou hast ysent me sory happes,
þus sone art went me fro.
I wende haue yhad of þee solas;
Myne hope is tynt, allas! allas!
And welþe is went to woo.
Son, þou doest vs stronge tourment!
Oure ioye is al away went!
ffor sorouȝ we shullen vs sle;
ffor often þou seiȝ þi fader & me
Erlich & late wepe for þee,
And ek þi wijf also.
¶ 'þo þat þee shulden haue serued trewe,
ffele tymes on þee þai þrewe
ffilþe & foule vryne,
And beten þee ofte swiþe sore;
And þou suffredest euermore,
And took it nouȝth to pyne.
Why woldestou cast þee in care,
Of hem to suffre swiche bysmare,
þat weren þine owen hyne?
Of alle þise seuentene ȝere
Ne woldestou noman tellen here
þou come of body myne."
¶ fforþ com þoo his trewe wijf
wiþ sorouȝ, & care & drery lijf,
And neiȝ for doel ded.
'Allas! she seide, my ioye cast,
Kare & sorouȝ ben in me fast,
As widewe wiþoute red.
Al my welþe is fro me went,
No womman is in swiche tourment
In lengþe ne in brede.
Al þis werlde, & it myne were,
I wolde ȝiue it fer and nere,
To seen his fairehede.
¶ 'It is no wonder of my doloure;
Yshadewed is al my myroure[MS. myrouþe],
And lorne is my briȝthnesse;
Myne herte may nouȝth lange dure.
Cursed worþe þou, dame auenture,
þat doost me destresse!
After fair weder falleþ reyn,
After wynnyng wep ageyn,
And care is after kysse,
Erly to day by þe morowe,
I ne wist of care ne of sorowe:
To bale is tourned my blisse.'
¶ þapostoile & þe clergie,
þemperoures & her chiualerie,
Token þat confessoure,
And leiden on a bere riȝth;
ffair & wel hij habbeþ hym diȝth,
wiþ menske & honoure;
To þe chirche of seint Bonefas,
wiþ þe corps þai token þe pas
wiþouten any soioure;
þe belles alle aȝein hem rungen,
Preostes & clerkes merily sungen
wiþ þat swete floure.
¶ Noman may telle wiþ tunge
þe miracles þat of hym sprunge
As þai þat body bere;
Deef & doumbe, halte & blynde,
Alle miȝtten bote fynde,
In maladie þat were;
Men þat weren in palesye,
Lunatik, oiþer in frenesie,
Bote hadden þere.
Swiche presse was þe poeple among,
þemperoures miȝtten nouȝth for þrong
Beren forþ þe bere.
¶ þai biþouȝtten hem in þis wyse,
þat folk was ful of Coueitise,
And tresore onon of sende,
And casten aboute siluer & golde,
Take it vp who þat wolde,
Largely to spende.
Nouȝth for þan in euery strete
þe presse was swiþe grete,
þai miȝtten hem nouȝth defende;
þai leten lygge þat tresoure,
And foloweden þat confessoure
þat day to þe ende.
¶ Riȝth at seint Bonefas chirche,
To seint Alexi þai gonne wirche
A riche monument:
Seuene dayes his frendes duelleden þere
ffor his body þat lay on bere,
And siþens hom þai went.
His fader / his moder / & his wijf,
Lyueden after in holy lijf
Trewely wiþ gode entent.
And whan þai dyeden alle þre,
þai wenten wiþ solempnite
To god omnipotent.
¶ þus ende & orde ȝee han yherd,
Of seint Alexi hou it ferd,
wiþouten any lesyng.
In þe worschip of god in glorie,
Out of latyn is drawen þis storie,
þorouȝ miȝth of heuene kyng.
alle þat habben yherd his vye,
God brynge hem to þe compaignye
þere Aungels ben wonyynge;
And sende vs, lorde, þi mylde mood;
ffor þorouȝ þee spryngeþ al good
wiþouten any endynge.
[A]lle þat wolle a whyle here dwell,
herkynnythe, and I woll yowe tell
A tale Sone of grete pyte:
Att rome, by-ffell in þat Cyte,
There somtyme wonnyd a man,
hys name was callyd eufemyan;
he was ryche in all thyng,
And euery day seruyd as a kyng;
he had I-nowȝe of worlldys well,
And seruantes with hym many and fele,
Thre thowesant to hym were atend|aund,
That weryd gold on here pendaunt.
In hys owne hous euery daye,
A custyume was that I schall saye:
there boredes that were fayre spred,
There pormen schulde be fede;
Of all pormen of ylk a gate,
there was none þat werned þe yate.
A wyfe he had, she hyght a gales,
An holey woman withowten lees;
She louyd god with all her myght,
And seruyd hym bothe daye and nyght;
She was of gode wyll, and hart Free
To all þe dedes of charite.
there she wollde clothe and fede,
and helpe men at here nede.
By twene theym chyllde had þey none,
there fore they made mykell mon.
theye were allwaye blythe and hende,
In hope that god shollde hem sende
Some maydyn chyllde, or some man,
That theyre herytages myght hane;
So long theye prayed with good entent,
that a man chyllde god hem sent;
whan they wyst þat hit was so,
Chanse theye leuyd bothe twoo,
Sythyn þey wollde for no need
Com to gedur in Flesschely ded.
Whan thys man chyllde was borne,
Fayne were here frendys therforne;
Theye bare the chylde to chirche A none,
And crystenyd hyt in the Font stone.
there theye callyd þe chylde Alexe;
Sone hit throofe, and wele hit wex.
Whan hit was vij yere olde and more,
hys freendys sett hym wnto lore;
he was sone Full goode of wytt,
And wnderstode the holy wryte;
he loued god in all his thought,
And of thys worllde gaffe he nought;
he sawe thys worllde was butt gylle,
for hit showld laste but a whyle;
neuerthe les whan he was elde,
lone and felde For to wellde,
hys fader puruyde hym a wyffe,
Wit whome he soulde led hys lyffe;
A mayden there was fayre and Fre,
Com of þe rycheste of that cette.
In holy chyrche vppon a daye
They were spousyde in goddys laue;
Atte here spousyng I wott there stode
Beshoppys felle and prestes goode;
Sythen theye made a mangery
With all the beste of here aleye;
All that comyn thyder þat daye
theye were seruyd welle to paye,
Com þey erley, com the late,
theye wer neuer wernyd þe yate;
there was nowder man nor knaue,
Byt mete and drynke he myght haue.
Euery man had there plente
Of claret wyne and pymente;
There was many a riche wyne,
In sylluer and in golde fyne;
Many a coppe and many a pece,
with wyne wernage & eke of grece;
And many A noder ryche vessell
with wyne of gascoyne and of rochell.
whan euyne com þat elke a gest
was gone to bed to take hys rest,
Eufemyan callyd hys sone Anone,
And bad hym þat he shoulde gone
In to hys chaumbur to hys fere,
And cowmfort her in hys manere.
Alex was to hym obedyent,
and ded his faders comawndement;
In to a chaumbur he com full ryght,
And redy there he founde hys bryght,
And toke here in his armys twoo,
And downe they layde bothe twoo;
'dame,' he sayde, 'nou it ys soo,
Of Flessche ar wee allso.
Noue may we be gladde of þis lyffe,
For thowe art bothe moder and wyffe;
For allwaye rede þat hit so be,
For nowe muste me wende frome the.
Whylys I was yong I made a vowe,
That I wyll Fullfell hyt nowe,
For to wende a pylgremage,
Noue woll I doo þat vyage,
And þou schalt lewe here at home,
agayne as goddys wyll I come.'
he yaffe her a gyrdell and a ryng,
all for a tokyng at þeyre departyng;
And Forthe he went that elke nyght.
To þe sse he come full ryght;
The shipe was redy, and ouer went,
wynde att wyll god hym sent.
whan he come Into a Fer contre,
he come into a ryche cytte,
Knowyn he wollde in no wyse be
Of no man þat shoullde hym see.
In that cyte was an Image,
That was lyke goddes wysage,
Many a pylgryme had hit sought,
For hit was neuer with honde wrought.
Alex herd ther of than t[e]lle,
Than thought he there to duell.
A none he yaffe Frome hym awaye
to powre men all hys monaye;
And bought hym pore man ys wede,
That none of theyme shoullde thak hede,
And axed his met eorly and late,
With poremen att the mynster yate.
All the mete þat he myght gete,
Bot euery day a melys mete
To pore men gaffe A noone ryght,
he lefft hym sylffe none ouer nyght.
there dwellyd he xvij yere,
And lede his lyffe in thys manere;
his Fader and hys modyr bothe,
Than he was to theyme Fvll lothe;
his fadyr made gret dole and sorowe,
Bothe on euen and on morowe.
'Alas!' he sayde, and wrong his honde,
'Why is my sonne went owte of lond?
I wende haue hade of hym a knyght,
with me to stonde In all my ryght;
nowe ys he wente þat was my blysse,
I west hym neuer do man a mys.
Nowe haue I none of my lynage
That maye welde myn herytage.'
Than sayde his moder, and wepte full sore,
'Noue shall I see my sonne no more;
I was full glade whan he was borne,
nowe ys all my Ioye forlorne.
I haue hade robbys maney and fayre,
Nowe woll I next me were the ayre,
Tyll I maye some tydynges here
of my sone that was so dere.'
than spake his wyffe, and wepte among.
'My leffe,' she sayde, 'was done wrong,
he toke me in my fadyrs bowre,
And brought me hydder with grete honouer.
And he has me nowe for-sakyng,
To Iesu cryst I wyll me takyne;
Sorowe and morenyng may I well make,
As the turtell dothe withowten his make.
Ioyefull schall I neuer bee,
Tyll I maye my leman see.'
hys Fader send bothe fer and vyde
Messengers on euery syde,
To seke his sonne where he was went,
Bothe Fer and nere where he was went.
Sythen affter yt befell soo,
Of messengeres there com too,
Ryght to the Ryche Cete,
There alex lywyd In pourte.
As they com In to a strete,
Alex com and shoulde hym mete;
Sone knewe he þeyme fwll welle,
And þey knewe hym neuer a dele.
lowde he spake vnder hys hoode,
'For goddes lowe do me som goode;'
Theye gaffe hym of theyre money,
For goddes lowe there in the waye.
whan Alex sawe þeye knwe hym nought,
he thanked god in all hys thought.
'lorde,' he sayde, 'I thank the
the grace þat thowe hast sent me;
Myne owne men that shoullde bee,
hate gewyn me of theyre cheryte.'
Alex dwellyd styll there
Fully xlij yere and more.
To chyrche he went euery daye,
his goode bedeyes there for to saye;
In to that chyrche, with owtyn fayle,
Was an Images of fayre entayele,
Of owre lady þat is so Free,
With here sonne wppon here knee;
That Images spake, þat was so bryght,
to the sexteyene vppon a nyght.
'Take,' sche sayde, 'my seruante swythe,
he hathe me seruyd all hys lyeffe;
Full offte he wolle to me lowthe,
hit is no ryght þat he is withowte.'
'lady,' he sayde, 'I knowe hym nought,
Nor I wott neuer where he schull be sought.'
She sayde, 'he sitteþe eorly and late
Withowtyn att the mynster yate.'
Anon he owte of his slepe brayde,
And thought what þe Image sayde.
And forthe went the sextayne,
And fownde alexknelyng In þe Rayne.
Fayne was he that he hym founde,
A-non he toke hym vpe be þe hande.
'A-ryse,' he sayde, 'my leve and dere,
hit ys no ryght þat thowe sitt here.
Com,' he sayde, 'my lady bade,
And there of mayst þou be glade.'
All that hard this tydynges,
Theye worshippyd Iesu, hewyn kyng.
Whan Alex sawe hit schulde be ryffe,
hys penance and hys holy lyffe,
here kepte he to haue mede,
In this worllde for his goode deede;
Bytt stylly he yeede a waye
In to a-nodr dyuers contre.
To þe se he cam in þat entente,
In to spreusse he wollde haue wente;
byt there com A storme of wynde & rayne,[MS. raynde]
And droffe þe shipe home a gayne,
That In a lytyll stonde they come
Ryght to þe cyte of rome.
Alex sayde þan with sympyll cher,
'Alas!' he sayde, 'wat do we here?
Myght hitt haue bene affter me,
here wollde I nought haue I-bee;
Butt gode wollde hit myght befall
I myght be in my fadris haull,
So that I myght vnknowen be
of hym and of his meyny.'
Forthe he vent vpe be a strete,
many a man there gan mete;
But there was no man þat hym knwe,
So was he lene and blake of hewe.
There come his fader hyme agayne,
With mayny a knyght and many a swane,
Than com with hym on ylke a syde;
Alex stode stelle theyme to a-byde.
'Syr,' he sayde, 'for goddes sake
Wyll yee thys porman In thake?
for his lowe þat dyed on Roode,
Gywe me clethe and manys foode;
and for his lowe þat went for the,
God sende þe grace hym for to see.'
This ryche man with stode þan,
And callyd one of his owne men,
And gaffe hym mete an dr[i]nk bothe,
And with pore men hym to clothe.
There dwellyd alex wythem alle,
Sewentene yere in his Faders hall;
There was no man, hye ne llawe,
yongne owlde, þat hym myght knowe;
his owne men for rebaundrye
dyd hym manye a welonye.
They hylde water wppon hys hede,
And gaff hym þat was in the dyche levyd;
But euer he hylde hym stylle,
And Alle he suffyrde with goode wyll.
A-gayne xvij wyntersende,
Whane he schowlde owte of þis worllde wend,
he prayd hym þat brout hys mete,
Prev[i]ly he shoullde hym gete
A lytyll ynke and perchemyne,
And all hys lyffe he wrote there In.
whan hit was wretyn, he hit Follde,
And In his hand he gan hit hollde.
And a none he dyed, I wys,
And dyght his sowlle to hewyn blys.
That ylke a daye in tym of masse,
whan all fowlke att chirche was,
A woyce cam frome þe trinite
To the bysshope of that cyte.
'Com to me,' he sayde, 'þat woll swynke,
And I schall gywe yowe met and drynke;
'Sek ye vpe my serwaunte, where þat he be,
That he maye praye for this cete.'
ollde and yonge, lesse and more,
All hard this þat were there:
For hit was no man, lewde ne leryd,
But of this woyce he nas a-Feryd.
Goddes seruaunte anon was sought,
but who hit was þey knowe hym nought;
That voyce sayde on that ylke a daye,
And tolde hym redyly where he laye;
'In eufamyans hous,' he sayde, 'is he,
That hathe my Serwaunt long I-be.'
the besshope And þe emperour
went in to euffamyans hous;
They axyd hym of syche a man;
he sayde he knwe there of noone.
on of his seruaunttes was thane thore,
That stode and lokeyd Alex by|fore.
'Syr,' he sayde, 'I trowe hit be
That poreman þat yee toke to me,
That long has bene in your hall,
he is an holy man with all.'
This ryche man went to hym a noone,
And founde Alex ded as ony stone,
But his vysage was allso bryght
As the sonne on þe daye lyght.
Than trowyd well eufemyan
That he was an holey man;
he callyd þe bysshopes & þe Empe|rowres
To se þat cors so presyowse.
In theye com a non ryght,
And saue the body þat was so bryght;
downe on knes theye fell thow,
And oder many that were þere moo,
And thankyd god In trinite,
That theye myght his seruaunte see.
The bysshope, as he stode hym nye,
A perchement leffe in his honde he see,
But he hyllde his hand so faste,
That owte he myght hit natt wrast.
'Sonne,' sayde þe bysshope, 'I praye þee
that in thye honde þoue lett me see;
Synfulle all thouȝe hit bee,
I haue powre and dyngnytee
For to lousse and for to bynde
Thym þat I in syn Fynde.
There Fore, sone, let me wetten
what ys in thy bocke wrytyn.'
The beshope toke þe boke so hynde,
That Alex hys hond on bynde;
the beshope þat Rolle red A non,
That þey yt harde euerychone.
There was there in redly tolde
Alle hys lyfe, yong and olde.
Whan hys Fader harde of thys,
That he was hys sone I wys,
'lorde,' he sayde, 'howe maye þys bee?
ys thys my sone þat I here scee?
Sewentene yere wyt All,
I had fynde hym in myn halle;
I myght nat wyt for none Asaye,
What he was, nyght nor daye.
"leffe sone," he sayde, "why ded þou soo?
Thowe saw I was For þe Full woo;
for þowe were not At my wylle,
And ewer more þou helde þe styll;
Thyne own saruantes þat sholde be,
myche harme ded þey to þee;
Theye kest water on thyn hede,
And gafe þe þat was in the dyche leuyde,
And euer þou bare þe meke and lawe,
For þat no man should þe there cnawe.
In heuyn ther fore þou hast mede:
Sonne, praye fore me, fore I haue nede."'
hys moder lyued in In longyng,
whan sche herde of thys tydyng,
She com Forthe with A raply rese,
As A lyon lept oute of A lees;
She weppyd And cryde sore,
As thay don þat arne woo.
'let me,' she sayd, 'my sone see;
I Fed hym on myn owne kee.'
whan she hym sawe, she Fylle downe,
All was A waye here Resonne.
whan she rose she stoode hym by,
She kyssyde hym, And sayd on hye,
'Sonne,' she sayde, And wept Full sore,
'Nowe schall I speke with þe no more.
Thowe hast be sought in meny A londe,
With messengerys, And with sonde,
Bot there was no man myght þe see,
And euer þou sat be owre knee.
lewe sonne, þou praye for mee,
That I may þe in bleyss see.'
hys wyfe þat was In chamber stokyn,
Of þys tydynges harde sche spokyn;
She com forthe in A sempyll pace,
Sory, I wott, welle þat che was;
She swonnyd at þe fryst syght,
That on here was blake, þat rest was wyght.
Than she sayd with mylde chere,
'Where hastowe be, my leman dere?
Full long I myght þe A-byde,
Fore thowe hast soughte pylgermages wyde.
Thowe hast beene frome long,
Forsothe I haue done þe no wrong;
Wyghe þe speke nowe I ne maye,
Nowe maye I weddowe be for Aye,
I maye be weddow And mayden dde,
And I haue done as ye me bade.
Thowe weddest me to be þy Free,
O nyght togeder when we were,
Bot, good leuan, nowe praye for me
That we to geder in blese maye be.'
The folke come fast owte of þe cete,
that ryche Relyke for to see.
Sone in a A lytell stonde þer was
Bothe grete throng And prece.
The emperoure, that stode þer þoo,
Sawe þe folke presyd ssoo;
Sylvyr in þe strete þey cast,
To lete the folke þat com so Fast,
Bot of sylver yaffe þey no force,
Alle held hem Fast to se þat corce.
At þe last with trawayle borne hyt was
To þe chyrche of seynt bonyfface.
whan yt was to þe chyrche I-brought,
A ryche tombe þere was wrought,
Of marbyll And of ryche stonys,
Craffetyly, And for þe nonce,
of sylvyr And of golde coloure,
They layd in þys Ryche tresowre.
Sythen cam on to hys tombe
Blynde And lame, dethe And dome,
And other man many And felle:
Thorowe grace of god þey hadden hell.
Be thys holy man men may ssee,
That god lowyght wele pouerte;
he for soke thys worlde all bedene,
And lowyd god, And yt ys sene
he for soke hys Fader, Moder, And wyffe,
And lyvyd A pore manys lyfe;
Nowe is he in Ioye þat last[et]he Aye.
God bryng us þere þat best maye.
Praye wee All þat yt soo bee.
Amen, Amen, For cheryte.
Sitteþ stille with-outen strif,
And i wol tellen ou of a lyf
Of an holy Mon;
Alix was his nome.
To seruen god þhuȝte him no schome,
þer-of neuer he ne blon.
his fadur was a gret lording,
Of rome a kyngus euenyng,
and hihte Eufemian.
Pore men to cloþe and fede,
In al rome, þat riche þeode,
such nas þer nan.
eueri day were in his halle
I-leid þreo bordus, forte calle
pore Men to fede.
Hem to serue he was wel glad;
he dude as iesu crist him bad;
he hoped þerfore to haue mede.
whon he was serued bi and bi,
þenne was he redi
to go to his mete;
ffor þe loue of Godes sone,
wiþ Men of Religione
wolde he sitte and ete.
¶ His wyf hiȝte dame Agloes,
to sigge soþ with-oute les,
þat muche was to preyse.
But heo dede þe same manere
as dede hir lord, as ȝe may here,
was heo nout at ese.
Children bi-twene hem hedde þei none,
þer-of to god þei maden heor mone
boþe dai & niht.
Iesu crist herde her bone,
& sende hem a ful good sone,
heor herte forte liht.
So sone was bore þat blisful child,
Alix boþe meke and Mild,
and of maners hende.
sone after wiþ gret hast,
þei Auouwede boþe chast
to heore lyues ende.
þer-aftur was hit not longe,
Alix couþe speke and gonge,
and was i-set to lere;
sone he was a wel god clerk,
& muche he loued godus werk
forte speke & here.
As time as he bi-gon to belde,
and was i-come to Monnes elde,
him was chosen a wyf,
Out of þe Emperors bour,
a maiden god with gret honour,
to wedden wiþ-oute strif.
¶ whon heo weren weddet þe furste niȝt,
in godus lawe as hit was riȝt,
& weren i-brouȝt to house,
Mekeliche he gon hire teche
to drede god of sunne is leche,
þat is Maidenes spouse.
He preched hire with al his miht,
of sunne heo scholde haue no pliȝt,
but holden hir Maidenhed.
Of Iesu þat Maiden clene,
in whom was neuere wem i-sene,
heo schulde han hire med.
Þenne tok he his gold ryng,
and ȝaf hit to þat Maide ȝing,
and seide to hire þus:
'Tac þis Ryng and kep hit me,
til þat godes wille be,
crist beo bi-twene vs.'
¶ whon he hedde don as i ou sei,
he tok his leue & went his wei
from þat Maiden fre.
A parti god with him he tok,
& al þat oþur he forsok,
and wende him to þe séé.
He fond schipes redi,
to on he wente priueli,
ouer forte fare.
whon he was ouere on þe sond,
he was in an vnkouþ lond,
þer he con neuer are.
He went him forþ with godus wille,
a feir cite he com tille,
þe nome i schal ou telle.
Edissa hette þe cite,
godus seruaunt forte be,
þerinne forte dwelle.
þe goodus þat he wiþ him brouȝt
of hem wolde he riȝt nouȝt,
he ȝaf hem pore men.
His Robe he ȝaf þer he sauh nede,
and cloþed him-self in pore wede,
for no mon scholde him ken.
He ede to A chirche hei,
þer pore men seeten in þe wei,
Almus forte take.
AMongus hem he sat a-doun,
and asked wiþ deuociun
sum god for Godus sake.
þat chirche was of vr ladi,
þer-Inne was a gret celli,
an ymage of hire sone,
Maked of a wonder werk,
þat nouþur lewed mon nor clerk
ne miȝt wite hou hit was done;
fforþi was þider gret sekyng
of on and oþur, old and ȝyng,
of al þat Cuntre,
fforþi þe pore þat þer ware,
Alle þe betere miȝte fare
for heore Charite.
Alix, of al þat miȝte he gete,
nedliche bote he moste ete,
he ne held to his bi-houe;
To pore men þat wolde hit take,
he ȝaf hit for cristes sake,
þat sitteþ us alle aboue.
¶ Nou is Alix dwelled þore:
his fader atom sikeþ wel sore,
and seiþ, Allas! Allas!
His Moder wepeþ niht and day,
& seiþ, Allas! & weila-wey,
þat euere heo i-boren was.
¶ His wyf wepeþ and makeþ hir mone,
& seiþ þat heo schal liuen alone
as turtul on þe treo.
Euermore with-outen Make,
Ioye and blisse heo wole forsake
til heo hire spouse i-seo.
Nou is fader, with dreri chere,
biddeþ his Men comen him nere,
as þei wolde haue heore mede.
He preȝeþ hem þat þei ben boun
to wenden & sechen his deore sone,
in eueriche a þeode;
þat ȝe ne dwelle for no þing,
er ȝe han herd sum god tiþing
wher þat he be.
Goþ nou forþ, and god ow spede,
þerfore i schal, so God me rede,
ȝiuen ou gold and ffe.
¶ Now wende þei forþ Alix sekande,
vchone to diuerse lande,
ȝif þei miȝte him winne.
Summe of hem þorwh Godus grace,
comen in-to þat ilke place
þat Alix was Inne.
He sat in pore Mennes rowe,
þerfore þei couþe him not knowe,
þei ȝeuen him Charite.
He tok hit wiþ mylde mod,
and seide, 'Iesus, þat died on Rod,
lorde, i þonke þe.
Lord, i-þonked be þou ay,
þat i haue beden þat ilke day,
þat i may for þi sake;
Of hem þat in myn owne lond,
serued me to fot and hond,
her Almus to take.'
Nou þis Men þat weren out-sent,
aȝein ham-ward þei hem went
to sire Eufemiane.
þei sworen alle bi heuene kyng
of Alix herde heo noþing,
as wide as þei hedden i-gone.
In eueri lond [þat] we han ben
we founde no mon þat him couþe sen,
þat to him couþe vs wisse.
"Nou, allas! þat i was boren;
boþe haue i nou forloren
mi Ioye and my blisse."
¶ In þis tale wol we non dwelle,
of Alix wol we nou telle,
þat riche pore mon.
Alix was pore Monnes fere
fulle seuentene ȝere,
fro þat he bi-gon,
Sittinge in a chirche-ȝerde,
among pore men an herde,
in a simple wede.
An ymage in þat chirche stoode
of his Modur þat died on rode,
for ur alre nede.
¶ Atte seuentene ȝeres ende
spac and seide wordus hende
þat ymage of tre,
To þe wardein of þe chirche,
& seide, "wardein, if þou worche
eny-þing for me,
"ffecche þou in mi sones nom,
for seuentene ȝer hit is gon
þat he haþ ben þer-oute.
I warne þe witerli
to dwelle her-in he is worþi,
þer-of haue þou no doute;
"He haþ serued heuene briȝt,
þe holi gost in him is liht,
& ȝiueþ him miȝt and grace,
þat his preȝere, with milde steuene,
is swete & god & heiȝ in heuene
bi-fore mi sone face."
¶ þenne seide þe wardeyn, 'ladi,'
he seide, 'i wolde fayn, & i
wuste whulche.'
'Go out faste as þou maiȝt go,
þou fyndest þer on & no mo,
bring him in þat ilche.'
þe wardein wente him out ful ȝare,
he fond him redi sittinge þare,
he brouȝte him in ful sone.
He seide, 'sire, ȝif hit be þi wille,
þou art welcome nou vs tille,
here-in schaltou wone.
'I was out aftur þe sent,
þorwh vr ladies comaundement,
þe in forte take;
with muchel honour schaltou haue
alle þing þat þou wolt craue,
for þat ladies sake.'
¶ þenne þis word bi-gon to springe,
& of him was gret spekynge,
for his holynesse.
þerfore he þouȝte forte wende,
to anoþur lond forte lende,
þer me kneuȝ him lesse.
þer wolde he no lengor beo:
monnus honour forte fle,
fro þat stude he wente
In-to Laodiciane,
forþ þe riȝte wey a-none,
as Iesu crist him sente.
In-to a-noþur lond he þouȝt,
godus wille til he hedde wrouȝt,
þer nomon hed him knowe.
Assone as he was in þe se,
forte wende þer he wolde beo,
þe wynd bi-gon to blowe;
þe wynt bi-gon þe schip to driue,
til þei bi-gonne to aryue,
as hit was godus wille,
In rome, þer he was fed & boren,
þer his woninge was bi-foren,
of al him þhuȝte hit ille.
whon he sauȝ non oþur won,
he bi-þouȝte him sone Anon,
wher him was best to be.
To him-self he seide and þouȝt,
'siþen þat Iesu haþ me brouȝt
in-to þis Cite,
'I con no beter red of alle,
bote go to my fader halle,
in pore mennes route.
I may sitte vppon þe rowe;
þer nis no mon schal me knowe,
so longe ichaue ben oute.
¶ Vppon a day Eufemiane
fro his paleis was he gane,
and ham-ward he eode,
with muche folk þat wel was diȝt,
boþe swein, [&] knaue, & kniȝt,
þat gode weren at nede.
¶ Alix þouȝte he wolde him mete,
& ron faste bi þe strete,
til þat he him mette.
whon he sauȝ þat he was neiȝ,
with a vois [boþ] loude & heiȝ,
Eufemian his fader he grette,
And seide with a milde steuene,
'sire, for godus loue of heuene,
haue merci of me.
Icham a pilgrim pore & naked,
þat haþ gret defaute ymaket,
sire, as ȝe mowe se.
Receiue me in-to þin halle,
þer þi pore men aren alle;
and graunte me þe mete,
And i schal preȝe niȝt and day
for þi sone þat is a-way,
þat Iesu crist him gete,
And grante þe, for his woundes fyue,
þat þou mai seo him ȝit a-lyue
þat was þin herte blisse;
And þe, sire, withoute strif,
Ioye of him in soule lyf,
crist þe to him wisse.'
¶ þenne Eufemian with-stod,
and grantede wiþ a milde mod
þat pore mon his bone.
He grantede him forte cloþe and feede,
and bad his men heo scholden him lede
to his hous al sone.
He grantede him, as i ou telle,
an hous al-one þer-in to dwelle,
wiþ-outen eny fere;
And a mon þat scholde him gete,
& bringe him boþe drinke and mete,
whon þat mester were.
¶ Nou Alix, as ȝe han [i]herd,
is dwelled in his fader ȝerd,
as a pore mon;
In preȝere, wakynge, and fastinge,
he seruede Iesu, heuene kynge,
in al þat he con.
Seruauns þat were proude and ȝinge,
þei driuen him ofte to skorninge,
as heo eoden vp and doun;
And ofte-siþes broþ of fissches,
& watur þat þei wosschen in dissches,
heo casten vpon his croun.
Of al þe schome þat þei him wrouȝte,
he þonked Iesu þat him bouȝte,
& ȝaf him miȝt þer-to.
He was meke in alle þing,
þer-of miȝte no mon him bring,
for nouȝt þat þei couþe do.
¶ Alix dwelled þere stille,
as hit was Iesus cristes wille,
seuentene ȝere
In his owne fader Inne;
kneuȝ him non of al his kunne,
neiþer fer ne nere.
Atte seuentene ȝeres ende,
he wuste he scholde heþen wende,
þorw grace of þe holi gost,
To Iesu crist, godus sone,
in blisse with him forte wone,
in lyf þat euer schal last.
He gat him enke & parchemyn;
al his lyf he wrot þer-in,
as he hedde i-lyued here,
And radde hit siþen vchadel,
he þonked god, so mihte he wel,
wiþ ful bliþe chere.
¶ Whon he hedde don as i ou say,
vppon þe holy son[e]day
þat com aftur nest,
With muche Ioie & muche liȝt
his soule, þat was so feir & briȝt,
went out of his brest.
Whon þat gost was went to heuene,
þer com a vois with milde steuene
in-to an holy stede,
þere as þe folk of Rome were,
godus seruise forte here,
& biddynge of holy bede,
And seide þis word with-outen fayle:
'comeþ to me, þat haueþ trauayle
or tene for mi sake;
Comeþ to me, i schal ou fille
with ioy & blisse, & al or wille,
þat neuermore schal slake.'
Whon þei hedde þis wordus herd,
þei weren vchone sore a-ferd,
& fullen a-doun to grounde.
As þei leȝe & hudde heor face,
þer com eft, þorw godus grace,
in a luytel stounde,
Anoþer steuene milde & meke,
& bad þei schulde ris vp, & seke
A godus mon of Rome,
'þat ȝe mowe, þorwȝ his preȝere,
of his godnes ben partinere
atte day of dome.'
¶ þei risen Al vp with bliþe chere,
& souȝte boþe fer and nere,
bi wei and [eke] bi strete.
And for noþing þat þei wrouȝte,
with þat relik þat þei souȝte
mouȝte þei nowhere mete,
Til þat vois, with wordes meke,
com a-ȝein & bad hem seke
in Eufemians house;
ffor þere scholde þei sone fynde
þat scholde hele doumbe & blynde,
a relik preciouse.
¶ þen þei ede sone anan,
& asked sire Eufemian
ȝif he kneuȝ such a mon.
He onswerde ful rediliche,
'i sigge ou lordingus sikerliche
of such ne wot i non.'
¶ þenne wente forþ þe Emperours,
Archadius & honorius,
& Inocent þe Pope,[Pope eras't]
Anon to Eufemians in,—
er þei weore þer, wolde þei not blin,—
with hem a god gret frape.
þen com a knaue sone a-nan,
& seide to sire Eufemian,
'go we, sire, i rede,
And loke, sire, at oure pilgrime,
þat ȝe han fed in long tyme,
wher he beo quik or dede.
'Ȝif he be ded þat was so meke,
he is þat mon þat þei seke,
i wot, with-outen drede.
He was a mon of holy lif,
of him com neiþer cheste ne strif,
ne vuel word ne dede.'
Whon Eufemian hedde þis herd,
he ron to loke hou Alix ferd,
in-to his hous ful riȝt.
He fond him ded whon he com þare,
his visage þer hit lay al bare,
as sonne hit schined briȝt.
In his hond he heold a skrit,
Eufemian sturte him forþ as tit,
to wite what was þer-Inne.
Bote with non scunes ginne
of þe hond þat hit was Inne
miȝte he hit not out winne.
¶ Whon he mihte no betere spede,
to þe Emperour he ede,
and tolde þat tiþande.
þenne come þei boþe forþ god pas,
til þei come þer hit was,
þe dede cors liggande.
whon þei come in-to þe hous,
þis Emperours þei seiden þus,
and on þis Maneere:
'þauȝ we for sunne are vnworþi,
we han kepinge not forþi
of þeos londes heere.
'And þis Mon þat we pope[pope eras't] calle,
haþ þe pouwer of vs alle,
and of al holichirche;
fforþi diliuere vp þat scrite,
þat we þer-þorwh mai seo and wite
hou we schul with þe worche.'
¶ whon þei þus hedde iseid heor wille,
þe pope[pope eras't] leide his hond þer-tille,
& he þenne let hit go.
Anon þe pope[pope eras't] let rede hit þere,
bi-foren alle þat þer were,
heringe his fader Also.
¶ whon his fader hedde herd hit red,
he was a-wondred & a-dred,
for serwe he was neiȝ ded.
As mon þat hedde þe deþes wounde,
he fel a-doun to þe grounde
as heui as þe led.
whon he hedde longe i-leyn,
& his stat was comen aȝein,
he made reuþful chere.
He tar his cloþus & drouȝ his her,
with delful cri & siking sor,
þat del hit was to here.
Muche deol hit is to telle,
houȝ he on þat bodi felle
of weopyng blon he nouht.
He seide, 'Allas! mi dere sone,
hou miȝtest þou þus longe wone
with me þat kneuȝ þe nouht?
Allas! nou hastou dwelled here
al þis seuentene ȝere
in myn owne Inne;
And þou hast boren þe so lowe,
þat þou woldest neuere ben a-knowe
þat þou wer of mi kinne.
Allas! allas! and weilawai,
þat euere I a-bod þis day,
þis serwe forte seo.
I wende haue had of þe solas
in myn elde; Allas! Allas!
for deol ded wol i beo.'
¶ whon his Moder herde of þis,
heo sturte forþ in haste i-wis,
As A lyonesse;
with hirself heo ferde to wonder,
heo ter hir cloþus al in sunder,
in a gret woodnesse.
Heo drouȝ hir her as heo weore wod,
& seide, 'for him þat died on rod,
Men, ȝe ȝiue me way,
þat I mai to mi sone go;
was neuer Moder half so wo
as me is þis day.
Ȝif me roum, & let me se
þe bodi þat was boren of me,
and fed of my breste.
Let me come þat cors to,
for wel ȝe witen hit is skil so
þat i beo hit nexte.'
Whon heo miȝte neiȝe hit neer,
heo fel þer-on with deolful cher,
& seide, 'Allas! mi sone,
Whi woldestou þus with us fare,
to leten vs dwellen in serwe & care?
whi hastou þus done?
þou hast i-seȝen þi fader and me
wepen & maken gret del for þe,
boþe erly and late;
And þou hast seuentene ȝer
vnknowen i-dwelled mid vs her,
in pore beggers state.'
Ofte-siþes heo fel doun
on þat dede cors al in swoun,
and custe hondes and feet;
And þat face þat was so swete,
heo custe hit & mad hit wete
with teres þat heo leet.
Heo seide, 'allas! þat me is wo,
þou were my sone with-outen mo,
wepeþ alle wiþ me.
Ichaue þe fed moni a day,
Allas! sone, weilaway,
þat i ne knewh not þe.
þou mist haue be a gret lordyng,
and ben honoured as a king,
ȝif hit hedde beo þi wille.
Nou hastou had despit and wrong
of þi þralles euer among,
and boren hit ful stille.
Allas! ho schal ȝiue to me
welle of teres to wepe for þe
boþe dai and niht?
Allas! allas! me is wo,
icholde myn herte wolde breken a-two,
þat i saiȝ nou þis siht.'
¶ þenne com forþ a dreri þing,
i-cloþed in cloþus of mournyng,
þat was his owne wyue.
Heo wepte þat pite was to se,
and seide, 'Allas! þat wo is me,
þat euere hedde I lyue.
Nou al my ioye a-wei is gon,
er hedde i hope, nou habbe i non
to seon him a-lyue.
Nou am i widewe, allas! þe stounde,
serwe haþ ȝiue myn herte a wounde,
þat me to deþ wol driue.
Allas! what is me to rede,
mi Muror is broken & is dede,
þat my likynge was Inne.
Hope of ioie nou haue I loren,
& serwe is newed me beforen
þat neuermore schal blinne.'
Al þe folk þat stod be-side,
þat seiȝ heore serwe so vnride,
a wepten ful tenderliche.
þer was non þat miȝte hem holde,
Mon ne wommon, ȝong ne olde,
and þat was no feorliche.
¶ þe pope[pope crosst through] com, & þe Emperours
bad bringe him forþ out of þe hous
& lei him on A bere,
And bar him wiþ solempnete,
forþ Amidde þe cite,
& criȝinge þat almiȝte here,
And seide, 'come seoþ þat holi mon
þat ȝe haue souȝt euerichon,
here he is in þis place.
He is founden, and he is here,
þat holi bodi on a beere,
þorwh help of godus grace.'
Alle þat wusten of þat cri,
þei ornen þidere wel hasteli,
þei tolde þeron nout a lyte.
An Alle þe seke þat þer were,
þat miȝte touche þat bodi þere,
þei weren hole as tite.
þe blinde hedde þere of him here siȝt,
woode of him heore wit fol riȝt,
þe halt here limes hole Anon.
Hit was non þat þider miȝte winne,
what seknes þei were inne,
þat þei were hole vchon.
¶ whon þe Emperours sai þe wonder
þei toke þe bere & eode þer-vndur,
with the Pope[crosst out] helpande;
ffor þei wolde be i-mad holi,
þorwh beringe of þat bodi,
þei toke þe bere in hande.
þei made sowen in þat cite
gold & seluer gret plente;
and þat was for þis skil
þat þe folk scholde hem with-drawe,
and þat auayled not worþ an haue,
þei tok no tent þer-til.
þei preced euer neer and neere,
forte come to þat bere
þat þe cors lay Inne.
þei precede wiþ so gret fors
þat vnneþe with þe holi cors,
to chirche miȝte þei winne.
¶ whon þei come to þe chirche,
A toumbe of gold þei lette worche
of preciouse stones.
In A schort tyme hit was diht,
ful richeliche and Al ariȝt
þei leide þer-in his bones.
whon þat holi cors was leid
in þat toumbe þat wel was grei|þed,
wiþ ful gret honour,
To alle þat weren in þat place
þer com out, þorwh godes grace,
a ful swete odour;
So swote felede þei neuer non,
as wyde as þei hedden gon,
of no spicerie.
þenne worschupeden heo Alle with o steuene,
Iesu, godus sone of heuene,
and his Modur Marie.
Iesu crist, þorwh þe preiȝere
of him þat we haue of told here,
ȝif þi wille hit be,
Graunt vs alle god endyng,
and in heuene a wonyng.
AMEN par Charite.

DIV3.HEAD: [Laud MS. 108, leaf 233, back.]
VITA CUIUSDAM SANCTI VIRI NOMINE ALEX. OPTIMA VITA.

LG.L: Sitteþ stille wiþouten strif,
And I schal telle ȝou þe lif
Of an holy man.
Alex was his ryȝtte name;
To serue god þoute him no schame,
& þerof neuere he ne blan.
his fader was a gret lording
Of rome, a kynges euening,
& hyȝtte sire Eufemian.
Pore men to cloþe & fede,
In al rome, þat riche þede,
Swich ne waster non.
Eche day were in his halle
Leyd þre bordes, forto calle
Pore men to fede.
Hem to serue he was wel glad,
& dede as Iesu crist him bad;
þerfore he hopede han mede.
When þei were serued by & by,
þane at arst was he redy
To gon to his mete;
þanne in drede of godes sone,
Wiþ men of religione
He wolde sitte & ete.
His wif hyȝtte dame Agles,
To seye þe soþe wiþoute les,
þat meche was to preyse;
Bote ȝe myȝtte do þe same maner
þat dede hire lord, as y seyde er,
Was ȝe nat wel atayse.
Child hem bi-twene ne hadde þei non;
þer-fore to god he maden here mon,
Boþe be day & nyȝthe;
Iesu crist herde here bone,
& sente hem a ful god sone,
here hertes forto lyȝthe.
When he was bore, þat blisful child,
Alex, boþe mek & myld,
And of maneres hende:
A litel after, wiþ greth hast
þei a-voweden to him chast,
To here lyues ende.
þer-after was it nat lange:
Alex coude speke & gange,
And was set to lere.
Sone he was a ful good clerk,
& meche he louede godes werk
fforto speke & here.
Sone whan he gan to belde,
& forto comen to mannes elde,
him was chosen a wif,
Out of þe emperoures bour,
A mayde good, of greth honur,
To wedde wiþ-oute strif.
Whan þei were wedded þe ferste nyȝth
In godes [lawe], as it was ryȝth,
& was I-brouth to house:
Mek[e]liche he gan hire teche,
To drede god, of sinne leche,
þat is maydenes spouse.
he prechede hire wiþ al his myȝth:
Of s[i]nne ȝe scholde hauen no plyȝth,
Bote kepe hire maydenhod;
& of iesu, þat mayde clene,
In whom was neuere wem I-sene,
ȝe scholde habbe hire mede.
þanne tok he his gold ring,
& ȝaf þat mayde, þat was ȝing,
& seyde to hire þus:
'Tak þis ring, & kep it me,
Til þat godes wille be,
God bi-twene vs.'
Whanne he hadde ido, as [I] ȝou sey,
He tok his leue & wente his wey
fro þat mayde fre;
A parti of his good he wiþ him tok,
And al þat oþer he for-sok,
he wente to þe see.
He fond schipes redely;
To on he wente priueli,
ouer forto fare;
He seyde he was a chapman,
& preyde, he moste wiþ hem gon,
ȝif þat here schip were ȝare.
fforþ he wente wiþ godes wille;
A fair cyte he com vn-tille;
þe name I schal ȝou telle:
Edissa hatte þat cite;
Godes seruant þer to be,
þer-inne wolde he dwelle.
þe goodes þat he wiþ him brougth,
Of hem ne wolde he ryȝth nowth,
Bote ȝaf hem pore menne;
his robe he ȝaf þer he sey nede,
& cloþede him-sulf in pore wede,
ffor noman scholde him kenne.
he ȝede to a churche-ȝate,
þer pouere men sete in þe gate,
Almesse forto take;
Among hem he sat a-doun,
& Askede wiþ deuocion
Sum good for godes sake.
þat churche was of oure leuedy;
þer-inne was a greth selly,
An ymage of hire son,
Maked of a wonder werk,
þat neyþer lewed man ne clerk
Niste hou it was don.
þerfore was þider greth sekyng
Of on & oþer, old & ȝing,
Of al þat countre;
ffor-þi þe pouere þat þer were,
Alle þe betere myȝtte fare
þoru here charite.
Alex, of þat he myȝtte gete
Nedliche bote þat him-self wolde ete
he ne held to his by-houe;
To pouere men þat wolde it take,
Al he ȝaf for godes sake,
þat is in heuene A-boue.
Nou is Alex dwelled þere;
his fader at hom seyetȝ sore,
& seyþ 'allas! allas!'
his moder wepuþ nyȝth & day
& seyþ 'allas & weylawey,
þat euere ȝhe born was.'
his wif wepþ & makeþ hire mone,
& þus [ȝhe] schal lyuen allone,
As turtle opon þe tre,
Euere-more wiþoute make;
Ioye & blisse ȝe wile for-sake,
Til ȝe hire spouse se.
Nou his fader wiþ dreri chere
He biddeþ his men him comen nere,
Als þei willen hauen þere mede,
& preyeþ hem þat þei ben boun,
To wende & sechen his dere sone
In euerich ilk a þede.
'þat ȝe ne dwelle for no þing,
Ar ȝe hauen herd sum tyding,
Where þat he be;
Goþ nou swyþe, & god ȝou spede!
þerfore I schal, so god me rede,
ȝiuen ȝou gold & fee.'
Nou gon þei forþ Alex sekynd
In diuerse londes to here tyding,
ȝif þei him myȝtte wynne;
Somme of hem, þoru godes grace,
Comen into þat ilke place
þer Alex was Inne.
he sat in pore mene rowe;
þerfore couden he hym nat knowe;
he ȝaf him charite;
& he it tok wiþ milde mod,
And seyde 'Iesu, þat deyde on rod,
Louerd, I þanke þe!
Louerd, i-her[i]d be þou ay!
þat i haue beden þat ilke day,
þat I may, for þi sake,
Of hem þat in myn owene lond
Serueden me to fot & hond
Here Almesse forto take.'
Nou þese men þat were out-sent,
aȝen homward þei ben I-went
To sire eufemian.
þei swore to him be heuene king:
Of Alex herde þei no tyding,
As wyde as þei hadde gan.
'In eche a lond þan haue we be,
We ne founden no man þat couþe him se,
þat to him coude vs wisse.'
'Allas, he seyde, þat he was born!
boþe[boþo MS.] haue I nou for-lorn
Mi ioye & ek my blisse.'
In þis tale wille we nat dwelle,
Bote of Alex wile we telle,
þat riche pore man.
Alex was pouere mannes fere
ffulli seuentene ȝere,
fro þat he bi-gan,
Syttynde in a churche-ȝerd
Amonges oþere men an herd
In a simple wede.
An ymage in þat cherche stod,
Of his moder þat deyde on rood
ffor oure alþres nede.
At þe seuentene ȝeres ende,
Spak & seyde wordes hende,
þat ymage of tre,
To þe wardeyn of þe churche,
& seyde: 'wardeyn, ȝif þou werche
Enyþing for me,
ffeche þou In my sones man,
ffor seuentene ȝer it is i-gan
þat he haþ ben þer-oute;
I þe warne wyterly,
To duelle her-inne he is worþi;
Whar-of ne haue no doute.
he haþ deserued heuene bryȝth,
þe holy gost is in him lyȝth
& ȝiuen him myȝtte & grace,
þat his preyer wiþ milde stephene
Is good & swete & mylde in heuene
Byfore my sones face.'
þanne ansuerede þe wardeyn
& seyde: 'lauedi, I wille ful fayn,
and I wiste wilk.'
'Go owt so swiþe so þou mayst go,
þou ne fyndest þer no mo,
Bryng him [in] þat ilk!'
þe wardeyn wente him out ful ȝare,
he fond [him] redy sittinde þere,
he brougthe him In ful sone;
And [seyde]: 'sire, ȝif it be þi wille,
þou art welcome vs vntille,
Her-Inne schaltou wone;
I was out after þe i-sent
þoru our lauedies comandement,[MS. comandemement]
þe in forto take.
Mechul honur schaltou haue,
& alle þing þat þou wilt craue,
ffor þat lauedies sake.'
Whan þis word be-gan to springe,
þat of him was a gret spekyngge
ffor his holinesse,
Sone he þoutthe forto wende,
To oþer londe forto lende,
þere men him knewe lesse.
þere ne wolde he lengere be,
Mannes honur forto fle,
ffro þat stede he wende
Anon to laodician
fforþ þe ryȝtte wey anon,
Als iesu crist him sende.
To A-noþer lond he þout,
Godes wille to han I-wrouth,
þer noman ne hadde him knowe.
Als swiþe as he was in þe se
fforto wende þer he wolde be,
þe wynd be-gan to blowe.
þe wynd be-gan þe schip to dryue
Til þat he be-gonne to Aryue,
Als it was godes wille,
In rome þer he was fed & born,
þer his wonyng was be-forn,
þei al him þoute ille.
Whan he saw non oþer won,
he be-þoutte him sone anon,
Whare him was best to be;
To him-sulf he seyde & þouȝth:
'Siþen Iesus me haþ hider i-brouȝth
In-to þis cite,
I ne can no betere red of alle,
Bote gon to my faderes halle
In pore mannes rowte,
I may sitte in þe rowe,
þer nis no man þat me schal knowe:
So longe Ich haue ben oute.'
Vpon a day sire Eufemian
ffro þe paleys was he gan,
And homward he ȝede,
Wiþ mikel folk þat wel waren dyȝth,
Boþe knaue sweyn & knyth,
þat gode were in nede.
Alex þoute he wolde him mete;
& ran forþ faste be þe strete
Vn-til þat he him mette;
Whan he say þat [he] was ney,
Wiþ a voys boþe loud & hey,
Sire Eufemian he grette,
& seyde wiþ a mylde stephene:
'Sire, for godes loue of heuene
haue merci on me!
Ich am a pilgrym pore & nakud,
þat gret defaute haþ I-maked,
Sire, as ȝe may I-se.
'Resceyue me into þin halle,
þere þine pore men ben alle,
& graunte me þe mete!
And I schal preye nyȝth & day
for þi sone þat is awey,
þat Iesu crist him þe gete,
'& grante þe, for his wondes fiue,
þat þou myttest him se in þine lyue,
þat was þin herte blisse,
&, sire, to habbe wiþoute strif
Ioye of him in soule & lif,
Crist þe til him wisse.'
þanne eufemian þer wiþstod,
& grantede him wiþ milde mod,
þe pore man his bone;
he grantede him to cloþe & fede,
& bad his men he scholde him lede
To his hous as sone;
And grauntede him, as [I] ȝou telle,
An hous allone þer-in to dwelle
Wiþ-outen eny fere,
& a man þat scholde him gete
And bringe him boþe drynk & mete,
Whan þat mester were.
Nou Alex, As ȝe habbeþ i-herd,
Is dweld in his fader ȝerd
As a pore man.
In preyere of fasting & waking,
he seruede Iesu, heuene kyng,
In al þat he can.
Seruantȝ þat were proute & ȝungge,
him dryuen ofte to heþingge,
As he ȝede vp & doun;
& ofte-siþes, broþ of ffissches,
& water, as he wessch here dissches,
þei caste vp-on his croun.
Of al þe schame þat þei him wrouȝthe,
He þonkede Iesu, þat him bouthe,
& ȝaf him myȝtte þerto;
He was þolemod in alle þinge,
þer-out ne myȝtte no man him bringe,
ffor nowth þei couden do.
þere dwelde Alex stille,
As it was Iesu cristes wille,
Seuentene ȝer;
In his owene faderes In,
kneu him non of al his kyn,
Neyþer fer ne ner.
At þe seuenteþe ȝeres ende,
he wiste he scholde hennes wende,
þoru grace of þe holy gast,
To Iesu crist, godes sone,
In blisse of heuene ay forto wone,
In þe lif þat euere schal last.
// he gat him enke & parchemyn;
And al his lif he wrot þer-In,
þat he had lyued here,
And radde it seþen eueri-del,
& þonkede god, so myȝt he wel,
Wiþ ful bliþe chere.
Whan he hadde I-do as I ȝou say,
Vpon þe holy soneday
þat com after nest,
Wiþ meche ioye & meche lyȝth,
his soule, þat was so fair & bryȝth,
Wente out at his brest.
When his soule was went to heuene,
þer com a vois wiþ milde stephene
In-to an holy stede,
þer al þe folk of rome were,
Godes seruise forto here,
To bidden holy bede,
And seyde þes wordes wiþoute faille:
"Comeþ to me, þat haueþ trauaille
Oþer charge for my sake!
Comeþ to me, I schal ȝou fille
Wiþ ioye & blisse at al ȝoure wille,
þat neuere mor schal slake."
Whan þe folk hadde þat word herd,
þe[i] were echone sore a-fered
& fullen doun to grounde;
As þei leyen & hedde here face,
þar com owth, þoru godes grace,
In a litel stounde,
Anoþer stephene mylde & meke,
& bad hem vp arise, & seke
A godes man of rome,
'þat ȝe mowe, þoru his preyer,
Of his godnesse ben partener
At þe day of dome.'
// þei risen alle wiþ bliþe chere
& southe boþe fer & nere,
Be weye & ek be strete;
Bote for noþing þat þei wrouth,
Wiþ þat relyk þat þei south,
Myȝtte þe[i] nowar mete;
Til þat voitȝ wiþ worde meke
Com aȝen, & bad hem seke
In sire Eufemianes hous,
'þer ȝe scholle sone fynde
þat schal hele dombe & blynde,
A relik precious.'
þanne wente þei forþ a-nan,
& askeden sire eufemian:
ȝif he knew swich a man.
he ansuerede redely
& seyde: lordingges, sikerly,
Of swich ne wot I non.
þanne wente forþ þe emperuors,
