Right about non.
'Goþ, besecheþ godes knyght,
þat crist serueþ day & nyght,
þat he bidde for Rome.'
¶ þe pope & his clerkes alle
Adoun on kneo þei gon falle,
Beforne & behynde,
And bede god Almyghty king
// þat he hem sende som tokenyng
wher þei myghte him fynd.
Iesu Crist, þat is so mylde,
Reuthe hadde of þis childe,
þat is in care bounde.
To hem seide heuene spouse,
'Goþ to Eufemianes house,
þer he worþ y.-founde.'
// After þis steuen vp þei stod,
& heried god wiþ glad moed,
Alle þat þere were.
ffor nought þe pope was so gram,
Eufemian he vndernam
wiþ wel sterne bere:
¶ 'wikke man, whi hastou hyd,
þat he ne moste er beo kyd,
þe holy man!'
þe emperour began to chide,
& fele oþer þat stode beside
toward Eufemian.
// Naþeles wiþ hem he ȝeode,
þe pope & many of þe theode,
toward his hous þo.
þe pope self & þemperour
Sought halle, þei souhte bour,
so wel so þei coude go;
// þei soughte him one stounde,
atte laste þei him founde,
þer he lay on bedde.
thoruh an hyne hem tolde be mouþe,
þat of his lyf mychel couþe,
And hem y-wissed hedde.
¶ Beforen þe bed þei stoden þo,
þe pope & þemperour also;
ac þei ne dorste ouer him trine,
þei wende he wer liues man;
Ac his gost was out-gan,
Brought he was of pyne.
// Eufemian adoun beyȝ,
his hond his neb he vnwrey
wiþ michel drede.
So suete smel of him teyȝ,
þat alle þat wer neyȝ,
wonder of him heuede.
¶ Out of his mouþ þer stoed a leom
Brighter þan þe sonne beom,
þat al þe stede atende.
Adoun þei fellen all on kneo,
to thanke god þat is so freo
Of wonder þat he sende.
Toward god he gan his hondes holde,
A writ betwene þei seye folde,
þei þat wer þer-inne.
Eufemian adoun beyȝ,
þat writ he drow & ȝerne tey
he ne myght it out-winne.
// þe pope her-of was adred.
In his herte god he bad,
þat him grante sholde,
þat writ þat was in his hond,
þat þei myhte it vnderstond,
betokne what it wolde.
¶ þe pope to þe bed beyȝ,
þe writ of his hond he teyȝ,
Right wiþ-outen gynne.
þat writ he began to sprede,
& to foren þe folk to rede,
þat weren þer-inne.
¶ þo eufemian was y-war
þat his sone lay þar,
& so long had wiþ him beo,
he fel in swounyng on þe molde,
'Allas,' he seide, 'þat euer .I. sholde so vnkynde beo.'
// Be a stounde he gan vp-stonde,
Tar his her & wrong his honde,
þat þe folk myghte rewe.
þei weopen & made reuly cry,
for him þei wer wel sory
þat þei him euere knewe.
¶ 'Awey, lord, þat herest my bone,
whi helestou my leoue sone
So long in my house,
þat wee ne moste him knowe,
And forȝete mychel wowe,
boþe .I. & my spouse.
// 'Awey, my sone, listou her,
& euer .I. hoped of þe to here
A-lyue þat þou were.
Me þenkeþ myn herte wile breke,
þat I. ne may wiþ þe speke.
Allas, þat .I. ded nere.'
¶ þe noyse into þe bour sprong
of þe sorwe was hem among,
þat in þe halle were.
his moder was wel sory,
& axed what were þat cry
þat she herde wiþ ere.
// Of hir sone men tolde anon,
þat out while was y.-gon,
& hou he was y.-founde,
& hou he hadde þer-inne woned,
& þis werldes blisse shoned,
And tholed harde stounde.
¶ þo she herde of hir sone,
þat he was aȝein come,
out of bedde she sprong;
Al hir yuel she forȝat,
And hardiliche held hir gate
Al þat folk among.
// 'war anon, par charite,
Let me go my sone to seo,
And myn oune fode.'
þe teres felle to hir kneo,
þat al þe folk myhte seo
þe brest orn al o blode.
¶ So sone so she to him come,
vpon þe liche she fel y.-lome,
And kiste it wel ȝerne.
she kist his neb, she kiste his hond,
on þe liche she lay, & nolde not wond,
Mighte noman hire werne.
// 'Allas, my sone, my dere lyf,
Soriere nas neuere wif
þan .I. am for þe nouþe.
ffor .I. hopede euer þe to seo,
Er .I. diede, & speke wiþ þe,
And kisse þe wiþ mouþe.
¶ Ac Al myn hope is y.-lore,
Nou þou list ded me before,
& wiþ me ne myght speke.
Lord Crist, .I. bidde þin ore,
Ne let me liuen namore,
ac let myn herte breke.'
// She wrong hir hondes & siked sore,
And to tar hire lokkes hore,
As she were woed.
'Leoue sone, bidde .I. þe,
Let me dien nou wiþ þe,
Mi lyf nis not goed.'
¶ Sone þo com his wif,
þat louede him as hir lyf,
To þe hous ago.
So sone so she com him to,
betwene hire armes she gan him fo,
& kissed his mouþe þo.
// 'Awey, my leof, what hastou do?
whi hastou holde þe so
In þin oune house,
þat non ne most com þe to,
So freond auȝte to oþer do,
Ne .I. þat was þi spouse?
// 'Allas, þat I. was woman bore,
Nou .I. haue þe forlore,
My leof so hende.
Sorwefulliche me is dyght,
Nou þou wiþ me speke ne myht,
I. ne recke whider to wende.'
// vp she stod beforn hem alle,
to drouh hir heer & hir calle,
as she were feye.
Bitter teres she let falle,
for hire þei wer sory alle,
þat hir wepe seye.
¶ So mychel sorwe þer was,
Bot who-so hadde a tong of bras
ne myghte it al telle.
þe day was almest do,
þe pope & þemperour also
Might no lenger dwelle.
þat liche þei let wake & shride,
wiþ pal & wiþ oþer pride,
þat þei founde þere.
wiþ michel ioye & hey song,
þe bisshopes hem alle among
þe corps to chirche bere.
// Amydde ryght þe heye strete
So mychel folk þei gonne mete
þat þei most astonde.
¶ Alle seke þat to him come
y-helede were .y.-lome
Of feet & of honde.
// þe blynde come to her sight,
þe crokede gonne to righte,
þe lame to go;
þat doumbe wer fonge speche,
þei heried god, þe soþe leche,
& þe halwe also.
// þe day ȝeode & drouh to nyght,
No lenger dwelle þei ne myght,
to chirche þei most wend.
þe bellen begonne to rynge,
þe clerkes forto singe,
Euerich in his ende.
¶ þo þei to þe chirche cam,
Glad þei were eche of ham
þat þer-inne were.
þe pope & þemperour
before þe auter of seint sauour
sette þe bere.
// Aboute þe ber was mychel lyght,
wiþ fair pal it was betyght,
& wiþ cloþes of golde.
fforto honour þis holy man,
of al þat lond folk þider cam,
þat fayn wake wolde.
// Alle seke þat þere were,
As sone as þei turned þe bere,
hole þei were anon
Of þe yuel þat þei hedde,
If þei in þe nome bede
of þis holy mon.
¶ To chirche com ȝong & olde,
þat holy corps to beholde,
þat þider was .y.-brought.
A wel gentyl marbelston,
To louke inne his holy bon,
Sone was y.-sought.
þe thridde day was .y.-come,
So me dide þe londes wone,
Men dide þe seruise.
þeder com more & lasse,
þe pope self song þe masse,
wiþ-outen feyntise.
þo þe masse was y.-do,
þe pope & þemperour also,
þe holy corps þei kiste.
þei nome þo þe holy bon,
& leide it in a marbelston,
y-loke in a chiste.
¶ Alle þilk þat þer were,
heried god wiþ loude bere,
& crieden mercy,
Of þe wonder þat he dide
In þe selue holy stede,
ffor loue of Alexij.
¶ Beseke we ȝerne & ofte,
Ihesu þat vs deore boughte,
þat he vs grace sende.
þat we mote him seruy,
And for þe loue of Alexij,
To his blisse wende. AMEN.
Lesteneþ alle, and herkeneþ me,
ȝonge and olde, bonde & fre,
And ich ȝow telle sone,
How a ȝong man, gent and fre,
By-gan þis worldis wele to fle:
Y-born he was in Rome.
¶ In Rome was a doȝty man,
þat was y-clepud Eufemian.
Man of moche myȝte,
Gold and seluer he hadde y-nouȝ;
Halle and boures, oxse and plouȝ,
And swiþe wel it dyȝte,
ffor alle þe sike of þe borgh,
ffaste þeȝ were y-souȝt þorgh,
And i-broȝt to his house;
¶ And set hem bedde wel & fede,
And to hem toke guod hede,
Him-selue & eke his spouse.
þis man hadde a wel guod wyf;
Hy ne louede fyȝt ne stryf
In al here lyue.
þe sike men wel ofte hy fedde,
And broȝte hem to hare bedde:
I-blessed be hy to wyue!
¶ Hy were to-gyderes ȝeres two,
And so þeȝ were somdel mo,
With-oute eny blede.
þeȝ bede god with herte guode,
þat hem sende such a fode,
To seruy him & drede.
And iesu crist, þat is so mylde,
Hem ȝaf grace hy was with childe,
þat guode Leuedye.
¶ Bothe be daye & eke be nyȝte,
Wel ȝerne hy þonkede oure dryȝte,
And so hy dede Marie.
þo þis child y-bore was,
Crist þeȝ þonkede of þat cas,
With wel glade chere.
Al-so as þe wone was,
As hy couþe with softe pas
þat child to cherche bere.
¶ þo þis child to cherche com,
To vnderfonge cristendom,
As riȝt it is,
His fader & his moder bo,
Swiþe blithe were þo,
And clepude it 'allexis.'
¶ Hy nadde bote þat ilke sone,
þerfore, as it is þe wone,
Hy louede him þe more.
¶ þo he was old ȝeres seuene,
þeȝ wissede him with mylde steuene,
And sette him to lore[MS. sore].
þis child wax, and wel y-þeȝ,
Cristis help him was neȝ,
And þat was wel y-sene;
ffor more he lernede[MS. sernede] in one ȝere
þan eny of his oþere fere
Dede in ȝeres tene.
¶ ffor sone þis child him vnderstod
þis worldis blisse was noȝt guod,
þe man þat him vnderstode,
Worldes wele he forsoke,
And to iesu crist him toke,
þat do was on þe rode.
He by-soȝte nyȝt and day
Heuene kynge, þat al þynge may,
He ȝeue him strengþe & myȝte
¶ Aȝens þe fend þat is a-boute,
To brynge vs in euel route,
Gostlich to fyȝte.
His bone y-herde þe kynge of heuene,
And spake to him with mylde steuene,
And seyde, 'allexis,
To-day þou myȝt wel blyþe be,
ffor þyne bone ich granty þe,
And my blessynge y-wis.
¶ And ich þe do wel to vnderstonde
þat þou most þolye shame & shonde,
Al for myne sake.
Into vncouþe londe þou most wende,
Sone þuder ich wil þe sende,
And al þy ken forsake.
In-to vncouþ lond þou most fare,
And soffry moche tene þare,
Al for sone myne.
¶ And suþþe þou shelt a-ȝe come,
And in þy fader hous [shalt] wone,
And þer-ynne fyne.'
þis childis fader fel on elde,
And his moder godis helde,
ȝeres hadde fele.
Hy wolde here sone sholde wyue,
To gladen hem in þis lyue,
And haue worldis wele.
¶ Hy by-soȝten him a mayde,
þat witty was and ful of rede,
I-come of heȝe kenne;
Woman hy was of hewe briȝt,
Hy þoȝte on crist day and nyȝt,
And wiste here fro senne.
ffor þo hy were to-gydere y-come,
þis mayde and þis ȝonge gome,
In godis lawe,
¶ þer was game and moche gle,
Ac, al for-soþe ich telle þe,
Ne eysede hem no plawe.
þe day was go, þe nyȝt was come;
þo seyde þe fader to þe sone,
With wel glade chere,
'Op arys, þou sone myn,
And go [þou] in-to boure þyn,
To glady þyne fere.'
¶ þo he was in-to boure y-broȝt,
He by-held þat may swaþel & toȝt
Of briȝte hywe.
Sone turnde he his þoȝt,
In fondynge he was y-broȝt,
His care be-gan al nywe;
He siȝte, & made sorweful chere,
Teres ouer his whyte lere
Bytere he let falle.
¶ Ne myȝte him gladye his fere,
With wordes ne with fayre chere,
þat stod y-shrud in palle;
þo it alles op a brake,
þe ȝonge man to his brede spake,
With wel fayre bere:
'Leman, haue guod day,
No lenger ich ne may
With þe by sene here.
¶ Wende ich mot fer out of londe,
And soffry tene & peynes stronge,
My synnes to bete.
Bothe ich mot, for godis sake,
ffader & moder myne forsake,
And þe þat art so swete.'
þo hy hadde y-herd þe tale,
Hire blesse turnde to bale,
A-swoȝe hy fel to grounde.
¶ þo hy of swoȝenynge a-ros,
Wel sore here a-gros,
With care hy was y-bounde.
Sone so hy myȝte op-stonde,
Hy tar here her, & wrang here honde,
And made reuful bere:
'Now þou wilt lef out of londe,
Loky ich may after þe longe;
Allas! þat ich ded nere!
¶ Allas my lef! what hast þou þoȝt?
In moche care ich am y-broȝt;
Of me þou hast synne.
After þat þou art a-gon,
Op breyde me tyt of manyon,
Of þyne riche kynne;
A-wey my lef, þat ich was y-bore,
ffor al my blisse is for-lore,
And now wexeþ my pyne.
¶ Allone her-ynne ich wille wonye,
And euere eft mannes mone shonye,
Al for loue þyne.'
'Leman, al for þyne sake,—
So doþ þe drake for here make,
Whanne he is a-slawe,—
Alle merthe ich wille forsake,
And euere-more sorwe take,
And shonye alle plawe.'
¶ He nam his gerdul on his hond,
And his mantel þer-on he wond,
And his ryng of golde.
'My leman, haue now þis to þe,
And oþer whyle þenk on me,
whanne ich ligge vnder molde;
Gret wel fader & moder myn,
By-lef her-ynne, & serue him
With wel mylde mode.
¶ þulke lord ich þe by-teche,
þat is of alle bale leche,
þat deþ þolede on rode.'
Out of þe borgh he wente anon,
So swiþe so he myȝte gon
Ryȝt to-ward þe stronde;
Sone a schip he fond þare,
þat was redy to fare
In-to vncouþe londe.
¶ In-to þe schip anon he wente,
And god wel sone such a wynd sente,
þat to þe lond hem broȝte.
þat schip was guod, þat water dep,
And oþer whyle sore he wep,
And was in moche þoȝte;
þo he in-to þe lond com,
He solde his cloþes euerichon,
And boȝte him pouere wede.
¶ Al his gold and al his fe,
Among þe pouere delte he,
þat hadde moche nede;
Sone he it vnder-nom,
þat he to one borgh com,
þat moche was & kete.
Sone so he þuder com,
To þe temple he wente anon,
God self to grete.
¶ Among þe pouere he wonede þare,
In moche sorwe and moche care,
ffor-to he fel to elde.
Al þat he spelye myȝte,
Be daye and ek be nyȝte;
His pouere feren he delde.
þo þe tydynge was y-come
To þe fader of þe sone,
How he was a-go,
¶ Him þoȝte his herte wolde breke,
O lepy word he ne myȝte speke,
ffor sorwe and for wo;
Ofte he siȝte & grente sore,
To tar his shroud, his lokkes hore,
þe guode olde man.
ȝerne he gradde godis ore,
þat he ne moste lyue namore;
To swoȝeny he be-gan.
¶ His moder with wel softe pas
Wente to bedde, & gradde, 'allas,
þat hy was y-bore.'
Nolde hy neuere eft out-come,
Ac þere hy wep for here sone,
þat hy hadde for-lore.
Alle þat þer-ynne were,
Hem-selue drowe by þe here,
And wronge hare honde.
¶ Be-soȝte god þat sholde hem lere,
To what londe þat he were,
And where he were a-stonde.
His fader & his moder bo,
ffor hare sone were ful wo,
þat ich ne may al telle.
ffor to sechen hare sone,
In what londe he were by-come,
ȝonge men he sente snelle.
¶ It by-fel opon a day,
þat ȝonge men nome hare way
fforþ riȝt by þe cherche
þere hare lord nyȝt and day,
Among þe pouere folk lay,
Cristis wille to werche.
He hem knew, and hy noȝt him;
Of hare guode hy ȝeue him,
As it wolde falle.
¶ He herede god, and made him glad,
þat he for his sone bad
Almesse of þralle.
Out of þe borgh hy wente sone
To here lord til þat þeȝ come
with wel guode spede.
Tydynges none hy ne broȝte
Of his sone, þat him soȝte
In vncouþe þede.
¶ þo þis ȝonge man y-woned hadde
In toune as a pouere ladde,
ȝeres seuentene,
God self wolde his care wende,
And to his fader him sende,
And bringe him of tene.
It by-fel in one nyȝt
þe mone shon swyþe bryȝt,
þe belward hym by-wende.
¶ þe leome of heuene he seȝ a liȝt,
And stonde ope godis knyȝt,
þat al þe cherche attende.
Sone amorwe, so it was day,
þat he by þis manne i-say,
Wyde he it tolde.
To þe cherche hy gonne teo,
þe holy man for to seo,
Boþe ȝonge and olde.
¶ þis holy man turnde his þoȝt,
Herynge of man ne kepte he noȝt,
þat frel is atte ende.
Out of þe borgh he wente anon,
To a water til þat he com,
þer-ouer he moste wende.
In-to þe schip he wente anyȝt,
ffor elles-whar he hadde i-dyȝt
In-to vncouþe londe.
¶ He wende fare swiþe riȝt,
Ac sone amorwe þo it was liȝt,
At Rome hy gonne a-stonde.
þo he in-to þe lond com,
In-to þe toune he moste gon,
His lyflode to wynne.
As he wente þorgh þe strete,
His owene fader he gan mete,
As he com fram his ynne.
¶ þo þe sone his fader mette,
Wel myldeliche he him grette,
And bad him of his guode.
þe guode man grantede his bone,
ffor al his blod gan menge sone
Ope his owene fode.
ffor ȝut him spak þe holy man
To his fader Eufemian,
With wel mylde mode:
¶ 'þat guod þat þou þenkest do me,
Iesu crist it ȝelde þe,
þat deyde on þe rode.
ffor ȝif it is in þyne mode,
þat þou hauest eny fode,
In vncouþe londe,
Crist ich by-seche par charite,
þat he wel to him by se,
Wher þat he be a-stonde.'
¶ So sone so he spak of his sone,
þe guode man, as was his wone,
Gan to sike sore.
His herte fel so cold so ston,
þe teres felle to his ton,
Ouer his berd hore.
To his house þe pouere he broȝte;
One ȝonge man him be-toȝte
To seruy him to queme.
¶ þere he wonede day and nyȝt,
And seruede god with al his myȝt,
ȝeres ȝut seuentene.
Some of þo þer-ynne were
þe holy mannes clothes tere,
þere hy leȝe on his bedde.
Ofte hy drowe him by þe here,
And of water and of broþ him bere,
And caste in his nebbe.
¶ Ofte hy him bete and burste,
þat þe lord þer-of nuste,
þo vnlede fode.
þeȝ clepude him 'waste bred,'
And weste þat he wer ded;
I-wis hy wer wode.
Al þe shame þat he dreȝ,
þe whyle he wonede his fader neȝ,
He þolede with mylde mode.
¶ And ofte to god he gan grede,
þat he for-ȝeue hem hare mysdede,
And broȝte hem to guode.
þe whyle he wonede in þe house,
Eche day he seȝ his spouse,
His fader & his moder.
Ac sone he wente him to þe wowe,
þat he neuere nere y-knowe
Of hem ne of non oþer.
¶ þe holy man him þoȝte þo
þat his lyf was almest ydo,
ffor siknesse þat he hadde.
Parchemyn he him wan,
And al his lyf wrot þer-an,
As he lay in his bedde.
¶ Al he wrot opon his bok,
How he his ȝonge wyf forsok,
þo he of londe wolde.
How he his mantel here by-tok,
And his gerdel þat was so guod,
And a ryng of golde.
¶ þat fel opon a soneday,
þat alle men of cristis lay
To þe cherche come,
Clerkes, knyȝtes, ȝonge & olde,
þe emperour with his erles bolde,
þe Pope self of Rome.
¶ þo hy þuder y-come were,
To here al so hy sholde þere
Hare seruise.
Al so hy hare bedes bede,
In þe luft hy herde grede,
In a wonder wise:
¶ 'Comeþ alle now to me,
þat synful haueþ for me y-be,
And a-fongeþ ȝoure mede.
Alle þat haueþ y-þoled pyne,
Honger and þerst for loue myne,
Ich ȝow wille fede.'
¶ Of þis steuene hem þoȝte wonder;
ffele wende it were þonder;
To gronde hy gonne falle.
What þis cry be-tokny sholde,
þat god hem sone schewy wolde,
A-kneo hy beden alle.
¶ Alle þat þer-ynne were,
I-herde ȝut anoþer bere,
Riȝt aboute none:
'Goþ, by-sechest godis knyȝt,
þat crist serueþ day and nyȝt,
þat he bidde for Rome.'
þe Pope and his clerkes alle
A-doun on kneo gonne falle,
By-fore & ek be-hynde,
¶ And bede god almyȝty kyng,
þat hem sende som toknyng
Wher þorgh hy myȝte him fynde.
Iesu crist, þat is so mylde,
Ruthe hadde of þis childe,
þat was in care y-bounde.
To hem he seyde, þe heuene spouse,
'Goþ to Eufemia[ne]s house,
þere he worþ y-founde.'
¶ After þis steuene, op hy stode,
And herede god with glade mode,
Alle þat þer were.
ffor noȝt þe Pope was ful gram,
Eufemian he vnder-nam,
With wel sterne bere:
'O luþer man, why hastow y-hud
þat he ne moste er be y-kud,
þulke holy man?'
¶ þe emperour be-gan to chyde,
And fele þat þer stode be-syde,
To-ward Eufemian.
¶ Naþeles, with him hy ȝede,
þe Pope, and manye of hare dede
To-ward þis house.
þe Pope self and þe emperour,
Hy soȝte halle, hy soȝte bour,
So wel so hy couþe.
¶ Hy soȝte him one stounde,
Ac atte laste hy him founde,
þer he lay in his bedde,
þorgh an hyne of the house,
þat moche of his lyf couþe,
þat hem y-wissed hedde.
¶ By-fore þe bed hy stode þo,
þe Pope and þe emperour al-so,
Ac hy ne dorste hem tryne.
Hy wende he were a lyues man,
Ac his gost was out a-gon,
I-broȝt he was of pyne.
Eufemian a-doun beiȝ,
His neb, his hondes, he vn-wreiȝ,
With wel mochel drede.
So swote breþ out of him teiȝ,
þat alle þat wer þer neiȝ,
þer-of wonder hauede.
¶ Out of his mouth stod a lem
Briȝter þan þe sonne-bem,
þat al þe stede atende.
A-doun hy felle, alle on kneo,
To þonky god þat is so freo
Of wonder þat hem sende.
¶ Op to-ward god held his honde;
A writ be-twixe hy seȝe y-folde,
Hy þat wer þer-ynne.
Eufemian a-doun beiȝ,
þat writ he drouȝ & ȝerne teiȝ,
Ne myȝte he it wynne.
¶ þe Pope her-of was a-drad,
In his herte, god he bad,
þat him granty sholde
þat writ þat was in his honde,
þat he myȝte it vnderstonde,
Be-tokny what it wolde.
¶ þe Pope to þe dede beiȝ;
þat writ out of his hond he teiȝ,
Al with-oute gynne.
þat writ anon he gan sprede,
And by-fore hem alle rede,
þat þo wer þerynne.
¶ þo sir Eufemian was y-war
þat his sone lay þar,
His armes he to-spradde,
He tar his her, he tar his cloþ,
And fel a-swoȝe opon þe cors,
So moche sorwe he hadde.
¶ By a stounde he gan op-stonde,
To-tar his her & wrang his honde,
þat alle folk miȝte rewe;
He wep and made reuful cry;
ffor him hy were wel sory,
þat he him er ne knewe.
¶ "A-wey, lord, þat art vs a-boue,
Why hele þou my leue sone?
To longe in myn house,
þat we ne moste him y-knowe,
And for-ȝute oure wowe,
And kesse him with mouþe.
¶ A-wey, my sone, now listow here,
And euere ich hopede of þe y-here,
A-lyue þat þou were.
Me þenkeþ my herte wil breke,
Now þou ne miȝt with me speke,
A-wey þat ded y-nere."
¶ þe drem in-to þe bour sprong,
Of sorwe þat hem was among,
þat in þe halle were.
His moder lay þere wel sory,
And axste what were al þat cry
þat hy herde with ere.
¶ Of here sone me tolde anon,
þat out whyle was a-gon,
And how he was y-founde;
And how he hadde þer-ynne y-woned,
And al þis worldis blesse y-shoned,
And þolede wel harde stounde.
¶ þo hy herde of here sone,
How he was aȝen y-come,
Of here bedde hy sprong;
Al hyre euel hy for-ȝat,
And hardeliche a-doun stap,
þe folk alle among:
¶ 'Remeþ me, for godis lone,
And leteþ me go to my sone,
I se myn owene fode.'
þe teres felle to here kneo,
þat al þat folk myȝte wel y-seo,
Hire brest al a-blode.
¶ So sone þo hy to him com,
Ope þe lich hy fel anon,
And keste it wel ȝerne;
Hy keste his neb and his honde,
Ope þe lich hy lay wel longe,
Hire ne myȝte noman werne;
¶ "A-wey, my sone, þou were my lyf!
Sorwere nas y-neuere wyf,
þan ich am for þe nouþe.
ffor euere ich hopede þe to seo,
Er ich deye, and speke with þeo,
And kesse þe with mouþe.
¶ Ac al myn hope is y-lore,
Now þou list ded me by-fore,
And with me ne myȝt speke.
'Lord crist, ich bidde þyn ore,
Ne let þou me lyue namore,
Ac let myn herte breke."'
¶ Hy wrang here hond, and siȝte sore,
To-tar here shroud, here lokkes hore,
As hy were wod.
'Leue sone, by-seche ich þe,
þou lete me deye now byfore þe,
þe lyf me nis noȝt guod.'
¶ Sone þer-after com his wyf,
þat louede him more þan here lyf,
In-to þulke house.
So sone so hy com him to,
Be-twixe here armes hy gan him fo,
And keste him with mouþe;
¶ "A-wey! my lef, what hastow y-do?
Why hastow þe y-heled so,
In þyn owene house,
þat þou ne woldest come me to,
So frend oȝte to oþer do,
Ne ich þat was þy spouse?
¶ A-wey, þat ich was woman y-bore,
Now ich haue þe for-lore,
My leman so hende.
Sorweful is me y-diȝt,
Now þou with me speke ne myȝt,
Ne reiche ich whyder to wende."
¶ Of hy stod by-fore hem alle,
To-drouȝ here her, and here calle,
As hy were veiȝe.
Bytere teres hy let falle,
ffor hire were sory alle,
þat here wepe y-seiȝe.
¶ So moche sorwe þer was,
Bote who-so hadde a tonge of bras,
Ne myȝte he it telle.
þe day him was al-mest y-do,
þe Pope and þe emperour al-so
Ne myȝte lenger dwelle.
¶ þat lich hy lete by-wake, and shrude
With palle and with oþer prude,
þat hy founde þere.
With mochel liȝt, and mochel song,
þat holy cors hem alle among,
Bischoppis to cherche bere.
¶ Amyddes riȝt þe heȝe strete,
So moche folk hy gonne mete,
þat hy resten a stounde.
Alle þe sike þat to him come,
I-heled were swiþe sone,
Of fet and ek of honde.
¶ þe blynde come to har siȝt,
þe crokede gonne sone riȝt,
þe lame for to go;
þat dombe were fenge speche,
þeȝ herede god, þe soþe leche,
And þat halwe al-so.
¶ þe day ȝede, and drouȝ to-nyȝt,
No lenger dwelle hy ne myȝt,
To cherche hy moste wende;
þe bellen hy gonne to rynge,
þe clerkes heȝe to synge,
Euerich in his ende.
¶ þo þe cors to cherche com,
Glad hy were euerichon,
þat þer-ynne were.
þe Pope and þe emperour,
By-fore an auter of seint sauour,
¶ þer sette by þe bere.
A-boute þe bere was moche liȝt;
With proude palle was be-diȝt,
I-beten al with golde.
ffor to worschipe þis man,
Al þat lond folk þuder cam,
þat cors by-wake wolde.
¶ Alle þe sike þat þer were,
As sone as hy touchede þe bere,
Hol hy were anon
Of þe euel þat hy hadde,
ȝif hy in þe name badde
Of þis holy man.
¶ To cherche come ȝonge & olde,
þat holy cors to by-holde
þat þuder was y-broȝt.
A wel gentel marbel ston,
To louke in his holy bon,
Sone was by-soȝt.
¶ þe þridde day was y-come,
So it is þe londis wone,
Me dude þe seruyse;
þuder come more and lasse,
þe Pope self song þe masse,
With herte wel blyþe.
¶ þo þe masse was y-do,
þe Pope and þe emperour al-so,
þat holy cors hy kiste.
Hy nome þe holy man,
And leyde him in þe marbel ston,
By-loke in one chiste.
¶ Alle þulke þat þer were,
Herede god with loude bere,
And cride him mercy,
Of þe wondres þat he dude
þo in þat ilke holy stude,
ffor loue of allexi.
¶ By-seche we þanne, ȝerne & ofte,
Crist self þat vs dere boȝte,
þat his grace vs sende,
þat we mote him seruy,
And for þe loue of allexi,
To his blesse wende. Amen.

ARGUMENT.P: A BOOK OF MORAL PRECEPTS AND PRACTICAL ADVICE (lines 1-105),

LG.L: SO mychel wisdom neuer y-herd was; as kyng salamon couþe:
Vche word wyt & wisdom was; þat com out of his mouþe.
Þe kynde he couþe of vche beest; & of vche quik þing,
And þe vertu of vche herbe; þat doþ on erþe spr[i]nge;
And þorouȝ queintise in book ywrite; þe fende to ouer-come,
Þat þise clerkes ȝutt to þis day; in priuete habbeþ some.
A Book he made of wisdom; þorouȝ his owen þouȝth;
Sum ich wil þerof telle; for al ne may I nouȝth.
Þe book bigan in þis manere; euerich wyt & wisdom,
Euer with oure lord it is; & fro hym first it com.
Who schulde þe rein-dropes telle; oiþer þe grauel in þe Cee,
Oiþer þe dayes þat euere were; bot ȝif it were he?
To douten god almiȝtty; of vche wisdom it is rote.
On erþe & at þine endyngday; of alle bales he is bote.
Ȝif þou louest wisdom; look þou riȝth loue;
Vnbuxum ne be þou nouȝth; to þem þat ben þe aboue.
Helpe þe man þat nedeful is; be aȝeins hym þat is vnmylde.
Be þou merciable to widewe; & to faderles childe.
Ne hide nouȝth þi wisdom; ne wiþseie nouȝth þe riȝth.
Aȝein stronge men & ireful; look þat þou ne fiȝth.
Answere þe pouere myldelich; to longe abid þou nouȝth
Forto turne aȝein to god; ȝif þou be in synne brouȝth.
// Ne bileue þou nouȝth to trauaile; oiþer to deþ[e] fiȝth,
For Iesu cristes swete loue; to susteyne þe riȝth.
Wiþ þe fole ne wone þou nouȝth; ȝif þou wilt good lerne.
Þou wisse hym þat litel good can; þe vnwise teche ȝerne.
Ne wilne nouȝth Iustise to be; bot ȝif þou cunne & mowe.
Þe vnbuxum, chastise wiþ riȝth lawȝe; & make þe proude abouȝe.
Þeiȝ þou haue a .M. frendes; take on þat be good & priuee,
Þat þou mowe þi conseil telle; lest þe oþer failen þe.
For summe ben at þi borde þi frende; ac at þi nede bihynde.
Best tresore is þine elde frende; þat men on erþe may fynde;
Þi trewe frende emforþ þi-self; þou miȝth telle þi þouȝth;
Michel solas he wil þe don; ȝif þou art in baret brouȝth.
¶ To Newfangel ne be þou nouȝth; lest þou finde vntrewe.
Þine olde frende þat þou fonded haste; bileue þou for no newe.
Faire speche is [ful] good þing; it passeþ many fon,
And makeþ many a good frend; & holdeþ hol many a bon.
Chese þe a witty hyne; & loue hym with al þi miȝth;
Of his Salerie wiþholde þou nouȝth; þat þou schalt hym with riȝth.
Þerwhile þi sones ȝonge beþ; þou hem chastise & lere;
Wite þi douttren with eye wel; þat þai haue of þe fere;
Selde þou make hem fair semblaunt; þer while þai ben þe mytte;
Whan þai schullen ywedded be; take hem a man of wytte.
// Honoure fader & moder; þat þe in-to þis werlde brouȝth;
Þe pyne þat þi moder had; haue it mychel in þouȝth.
Who so honoureþ fader & moder; þe lenger he worþe alyue;
His hous & al his erþlich þing; þe better schal yþriue.
To þe seke gladlich þou go; þan doostou as þe kynde.
In euerych dede þat þou doost; þine endynge haue in mynde.
¶ Ne chide nouȝth wiþ no foule speker; with riche ne plede þou noȝt;
For oft þe riȝth, þorouȝ gret mede; is in-to wrong y-brouȝth.
Mid a fole, of þi þing; ne make þou non In mone.
Wiþ a Man þat fool-hardy is; ne goo þou nouȝth alone.
To fool ne to non vncouþ man; þi conseil [þou] ne telle,
For þe fool, bot his foly; noþing ne loueþ wel.
Ne biholde no faire wymmen; þat þai ne chaunge þi þouȝt;
Ne loue no womman with þine hert; þat sche ne gile þe nouȝt;
Ne biholde nouȝth in þe strete; aboute fram þing to þing.
Ȝif a liþer man doþ þe vnriȝth; ne haue þerof no likyng.
Dele þi frendes & pouere men; þi good by þi daye;
Ne bileue it nouȝth to oþer men; lest þai þe bitraye.
Ne delite þe nouȝth to gete children; many & vnmylde,
ffor ȝut þe were better; to deye wiþouten childe.
¶ Amended is al a cuntre; wiþ a Man þat is wys.
And for a liþer man; mychel enpaired I-wis.
A riche werk of dronkelew man; selde is yfounde,
For Tauerne & leccherie; many man bringeþ to grounde
Noiþer þi frende ne þi foo; ne telle þou þi priuete;
For bot he be þe better frend; ȝif he wot any yuel by þe
Þat þou ne most þe more hym bowȝe; ȝif þou misseist hym ouȝt,
Þat yuel þat he wot by þe; he nyll it hele nouȝth.
Vndernyme þi frend; ȝif þou seest hym mysdo;
Ȝif he is a fool or þi foo; ne do þou nouȝth so.
Riche ȝiftes & presentȝ; maken þise Iuges blynde,
Þat þai cunnen yse þe riȝth; þe wrong sone þai fynde.
// wisdom yheled, litel is worþ; oiþer treuþ ihyd;
Bot boþe þai wexen swiþe; ȝif þai ben y-kyd.
Good is, wisdom to schewe; & to hely folie;
For þe fool ne can hele noþing; bot he it out wrie;
His hert is as a vessel; þat boþome ne haþ non;
Whan any þing þerinne comeþ; it goþ out onon.
A fool, men mowen wel yknowe; for oft he goþ aboute
With erandes to many hous; & oft he stant withoute,
And goþ to a windowe stillelich; & soft lokeþ þer-inne,
Oiþer herkneþ þerat what men; seien þere wiþinne.
Sone & lovde he wil liȝe; whan he hereþ foly telle:
A wise man wolde aschamed be; ȝif swich a cas hym bifelle.
Vche word þat at his mouþe schal come, schal be by mesure;
Hym is loþ to telle myche; ac leue myche to here.
Ȝut þre wisdoms lerne of me; ne þenche nouȝth to longe;
Be nouȝth sory for no los; ne after noþing longe,
Namelich þat þou ne miȝth nouȝth haue; ne nouȝth þerfore ne care.
Ne al þat þou herest, ne leue þou nouȝth; ȝif þou wilt wel fare.
An vntauȝt childe his fader schent more; þan þei hem selue don;
Þe man þat techeþ his children wel; sore saweþ his fon.
Þre þinges on erþe beþ; þat men mowen nouȝth y-knowe:
Whiche hij ben, I schal ȝou telle; boþe to heiȝe & lowe:
Þe fissches weie in þe Cee; þe snakes weie on erþe,
And þe foules waie in þe sky; þe werst is þe fierþe:
Þat is, childes waie in his ȝouþe; ȝif it haþ his wille.
For many a foule waie it will goo; & selde sitt stille.
Þis book made Salamon; of þise wisdoms & more:
To mychel he loued leccherie; for al his wise lore,
Seuenty wyues in spousehode; he helde al his lyf,
And þre hundreþ in leccherie; þat non þerof was his wyf.
Fourty wyntren he was kyng; & died in þe fourtide ȝere.
Telle men miȝtten þat he were saf; ȝif leccherie nere.
Foure hundreþ ȝer & seuentene; it was þo he died, & mo,
Þat þe folk of Israel; out of Egipte gunnen go.
Affter kyng Salomons deþ; Roboam his sone
Was of þat londe kyng ymade; as it was þe wone.
Þat folk cried on hym a day; þat he a-legge scholde
Þe seruage þat his fader hem made; þe better serue hym þai wolde.
Þerfore with alle his olde men; þe kyng went to conseile:
Þai radden hym mylde forto be; þe more it wolde hym availe.
He cleped forþ his ȝonge folk; as he hym self was,
& axed wheþer þe reed was good; þai seiden þat it nas;
Bot "be þou sterne & dredeful; & þan wil þai ben good;
Ne schaltou hem neuere good holde; bot with sterne mood."
¶ Þe kyng þis conseil loued wel; his bondemen he lete fecche.
"Wene ȝe for my fader was wys; þat ich wil be a wrecche.
In þe left fynger þat ich haue; strengþe þere is more
Þan was in al my fader schulder; for al his wise lore
ȝif he ȝou brouȝth in seruage; to more I wil ȝou drawe.
Wene ȝe þeiȝ ich be ȝong; þat ich ne couþe ȝou lawe?"
Þis folk crieden ȝerne & wepen; sore þai hem dradd;
Ac for noþing þai miȝtten do; oþer word þai nadd.
ÞO þai weren from hym ywent; gret conseil þai token.
Þe ten kyndes of israel; for kyng þai hym forsoken,
And made hem a newe kyng; ne stode hem of hym non eie;
ffor þere ne leued wiþ hym; bot þe kyndes tweie,
Bot þe kynde of Beniamyn; & þe kynde of Iudas;
Alle þe kyndes of þe oþer ten; aȝeins hym fast was.
Þe kyng sent messagers to hem; & gret doel to hym he nom;
Wiþ stones þai slowȝen his messagers; þat to hem from hym com.
Affter þai maden Ieroboam kyng; wel he gan hem paie;
And euere þe kyngdom departed is ȝut to þis daye.
Þe kyngdom of þe tweie kyndes; Iudee ycleped is;
Þerinne oure lord was ybore; in Bethleem iwis.
Þe kyngdom of þe ten kyndes; ycleped is israel;
Þere miȝth Roboam þe kyng; acursy fole conseil.
Ofte eye & pride, harme doeþ; þere men miȝth yse;
So riche a man in londe nis; þat mowe al-one be;
So riche a kyng in þe werlde nys; þat poure begger he nere,
ffor al þe richesse þat he haþ; ȝif vche man his fo were.
IT bifel in israel; by þe kyngesday, swiche a cas:
Þere was a wise prophete; Elye ycleped he was.
In wildernesse he woned; þe good prophete Elye,
ffor þe kyng awaited hym to sle; for his prophecie.
A morewen & an euen a Rauen; þere com vche a day,
And brouȝth þe prophete mete; in wildernesse þere he lay.
Siþen as oure lorde hym hete; to a toun he wende,
And seiȝ a widewe gadre wood; onon to hir he kende.
Þere he woned longe wiþ hire; a day þer fel a cas
Þat þe widewe son died; he was yhote Ionas;
Elie arered hym fram deþ to lyue; þorouȝ goddes sonde;
And siþen he was a prophete; þe wisest in þe londe.
ffor wel longe afterward; oure lord bad Ionas gon
To þe Cite of Niniue; þat schulde haue ben fordon
ffor synne þat þai hadden ydon; Ionas was adradd,
Ac forto prechen þider he ȝede; as oure lord hym bad.
// To þe hil of Oreb; Ely redy wende
Þere Moyses in þe brennyng þorne; oure lorde kende:
ffourty dayes he was þiderward; þat he ne ete ne dronk
As it goddes will was; he had mychel þonk.
Þere oure lorde spak wiþ hym; & hete hym good lyf lede,
And wende aȝein to israel; & noþing ne drede.
"// A Man þat hatte Elisee; by þe waie þou schalt fynde;
Þou schalt hym take forþ wiþ þe; þat he ne leue bihynde."
Elie þe prophete went forþ; til he in-to desert cam.
He fonde Elyse gon on þe pleyn; with hym forþ he hym nam
To þe londe of israelMS. isrk.; þai nadden of þe kyng non eye.
Elise fonde anoþer prophete; & þider þai wenten beie.
Þo lay þe kyng sore seek; & þo it was hym ysed,
Elye tolde his messagers; þat he schulde be ded.
He hete his men wende after hym; þat þai sparen ne scholde;
He wende, ȝif he miȝth hym haue hadd; þat he hym hele wolde.
Þei wenten forþ & comen to Elye; "goddes man" þai seide:
"Þe kyng hete þe come & speke with hym; ȝif þou couþest hym rede."
Elie seide "ȝif ich am goddes man; I. bid god al-one,
Þat wilde fire come fram heuen adoun; & brenne ȝou vchone."
Amyd þis word onon; fire fram heuen com,
And brent þise men al to dust; þere was an hard dom.
Sore alonged was þe kyng; after hym ylome;
Tueie he sent of oþer men; þo þai nouȝ[th] ne come.
Þai seiden as þe oþer deden; þo þai Elye seie;
And as þe oþer þai weren serued; ibrouȝth on liȝth leie.
þo þai ne comen nouȝth aȝein; þe kyng þouȝth longe,
And lete sende after hym; wise men & stronge.
// Ȝerne þai crieden mercie; þo þai Elye seiȝe:
"Haue mercy on þe kyng; or elles he schal diȝe."
Þerof seide Elye; "Siker he may be.
Ac, forto paye his corage; ich wil hym ones see."
Elye went forþ to þe kyng; & seide he schulde be ded;
And sone he died þerafter-ward; as he had ysed.
Elie & Elisee in þe londe; wide aboute went,
For to tellen of prophecie; as oure lorde hem sent.
As þai precheden goddes lawe; from heuen þere aliȝth
A fyry hors & a cart;—boþe þai weren wel briȝth;—
Elye þerinne went; þat hors hym drouȝ vp on heiȝ
In þe cart to heuen; þat men neuer eft hym ne seiȝ.
// Riȝth to heuen ne segge ich nouȝth; þat he euer come,
For he schal haue fleschlich lyf; forto aȝeins þe day of dome.
We rede nouȝth bot of two Men; þat hennes alyue went,
Enok & Elye; as god hem after sent.
Boþe þai wonen in paradys; & boþe þai schullen aliȝth
Aȝeins þe day of dome; & wiþ antecrist fiȝth.
Anticrist hem schal boþe sle; & siþþen þai schullen wende
To þe blisse of heuen; & wonen þere wiþouten ende.
ÞO Ely in þis fair cart; to heuen was ylad,Elye
Elisee his felawe; was sory, & nouȝth glad.
He ȝede to don his prophecie; in þe londe of Ierico:
Þere he fonde a liþer welle; þat many man dude wo,
ffor it wolde wex & sprede; wide & brode ilome,
Ne miȝth þe erþe bere no fruyt; þere þe water come.
Þe prophete blissed salt; & in þe watere cast;
Þe liþerhede þat þerinne was; miȝth no lengere last;
It bicom þe best watere; þat euer miȝth ben;
Al þat it comeþ-neiȝ; þe bettere schal þeen.
ffor þe miracle þat men þo say; þat white salt had ydo,
Whan þe preest makeþ haliwater; salt he doþ þerto.
A Womman cried on Elisee; as sche hym mette,Eliseus
& seide, men took al hir good; for hire hosebonde dette,
& þat sche nadd nomore good; bot Oile alite.
Elisee bad hire take þerof; & in vche vessel it pite
Þat sche had in al hire hous; & þo sche had ydo þis,
Euerich vessel was ful; of good oyle Iwis.
Þis womman had þer þorouȝ; ynouȝ of al good
fforto ȝelde her dettes; & to hire lyues food.
It bifel þat men of Babiloyne; weren of liþer bileue:
Þai honoureden a fals god; a morewe & ek an eue.
A Wise prophete was in þat londe; þat hiȝth Danyel.¶Danyel.
He com & told þe kyng 'fore; his men bileueden noȝt wel.
Ȝiue me power ouer hem; & ich hem wil bringe of dawe.'
Þan seide þe kyng to hym; "þat were no wise lawe."
Þat folk þo þai herden þis; þe kyng þai comen to:
"Ȝiue vs" þai seiden "Danyel; oure will with hym to do,
Oiþer we schullen þe sle; er we hennes gon."
Þe kyng was of hem sore adrad; & graunted hem onon.
Onon þai token Danyel þo; & casten hym in-to a pytte,
Þere seuen hungri lyouns weren; þereinne all ydytte,
ffor þai hym strangli scholden; ac þai deden hym non harme;
Bot whan þat he was sett adoun; þai leneden in-to his barme.
A Man þere was þat hiȝth Abacuc; in-to þe felde he went,¶ Abacuk.
Repmen forto bere mete; sone he hym þider sent.
Þe Aungel hym bad abide; & to Danyel it bere.
Sone he seide 'he nolde'; & ȝaf hym liȝth ansuere.
Þe aungel took hym by þe top; & bare hym forþ þer myde,—
Hym had ben bettere to haue ygo; þan so fer to haue iryde,—
& so hym he bare to Danyel; & þo he com hym to,
He ȝaf hym þe mete þat he bare; & lete Abacuc go.
Þo Danyel had seueniȝth; ibe in þe dep pytt,
Þe kyng loked to his lyouns; & lete hem vndytt.
¶ Alyue he fond Danyel; gret wonder he hadde.
Wiþ gret ioye he took hym vp; & to his fon hym lad.
Þe men þat brouȝtten hym þere; he lete nyme fast,
And euerych after oþere; amonge þe lyouns cast.
Sone hadden þe Lyouns; forswelewed hem vchone;
And so oure lorde euer among; takeþ wreche of his fon.
Þapostles, forto þai weren yslawe; precheden cristendom;
And many man after hem; good prechour bycom.
And now þise freres don also; prechen aboute ylome,
ffor of prechyng it worþe nede; er þe day of dome.
ÞE first signe þer aȝeins; as oure lord hym-self sede,
Hungere schal on erþe be; treccherie & falshede,
Batailes & litel loue; sekenesse & haterede;
& þe erþe schal quaken; þat vche man schal drede;
Þe mone schal turne to blood; þe sunne to derkhede;
Antecrist schal on erþe gon; & prechen his li er hede.
He schal go bot in þe holy londe; þere oure lord ȝede,
& his deciples in-to al þe werlde; his yuel wordes wil bede.
As þai speken, þai schullen do; miracles grete & ryue;
Bot we ne fynde nouȝth þai mowe; arere þe ded to lyue.
Bot in-to cursed gostes; fendes willeþ go,
fforto bere hem witnesse; of al þat he seiþ hem to.
Þise grete clerkes & wise; aȝein hym schullen speke,
fforto holden vp cristendom; þat men it nouȝth ne breke.
Bot many of þise foles siggen; in her hastite,
Þat clerkes schullen fordo þis werld; bot so schal it noȝt be,
Bot þe fals clergie; þat antecrist schal of preche;
& fele þat in godenesse schulden be; liþer he wil hem teche.
Ac so wys clerk ne worþ þer non; þat ne schal haue to don ynouȝ
fforto disputen aȝeins hym; þeiȝ he haue þe wouȝ.
Many men schullen turne; to yuel, men may drede,
ffor on erþe men may se; to liþer, stedfast hede.
Oure lord let hym on erþe gon; for þat he wil fonde
Whiche men of stedfastnesse beþ; & cristendom vnderstonde.
Tueie men ben in paradys; Enok & Elye;
Þai ne suffreden neuer deþ; as we han seid twie.
Aȝeins þe day of dome; þai schullen on erþe aliȝth,
And her eiþer after oþer; aȝeins Antecrist fiȝth.
Anticrist hem schal boþe sle; & fele Men willen þerfore
Turne to her bileue; & make her soules forlore.
Atte last schal come þe holi gost; in fourme of swerd al[i]ȝt,
& Anticrist to deþ smyte; þorouȝ his swete miȝt.

DIV1.HEAD: St. Jeremie's 15 Tokens before Doomsday. WITH LAMENTACIO ANIMARUM, WHAT OUR LORD SHALL DO AND SAY ON THAT DOOMSDAY; AND A SONG OF JOY AND BLISS, TO PRAISE THAT SWEET DEW, CHRIST.

ARGUMENT.P: (See other englisht copies of these '15 Tokens' attributed to St. Jerome, in my Early English Poems (Philolog. Soc. 1862), p. 7-12, and p. 162-4 (from Metrical Homilies, ed. Small, before publication); my Hymns to the Virgin and Christ (E. E. T. S., 1867), p. 118-125; Dr Morris's 'Hampole's Pricke of Conscience' (Philolog. Soc.), p. 135, l. 4738, &c, and Cursor Mundi (E. E. T. Soc.), p. 1282-1298, Part IV, and p. 1616-18 (from the Edinburgh MS), in the Appendix, Part V; Mr T. Wright's Chester Plays (copid by Geo. Bellin in 1592), vol. ii. 147-9; and in the same vol., p. 219-21 (from Harl. MS. 913, ab. 1309 A.D.), and p. 222-4 (from Harl. 2255); Mr Small's Northern 'Metrical Homilies', p. 25-6, given also in Morris and Skeat's Speci|mens of Early English, 1298-1393, p. 83-5; Sir David Lyndesay's Monarche, book iv, l. 5462 (in Skeat's Specimens, 1394-1579, p. 254-6), &c, &c, &c. Old Friesic has a version of these 15 Tokens, says Mr Skeat: see Richtofen, Friesische Rechtsquellen, p. 130. Mr Small says that 'no copy of the original is to be found in the Benedictine edition of Jerome's Works'; and Mr Wright states that 'others say they are first found in the Prognosticon futuri seculi of Julianus Pomerius, a theologian, who died in the year 690'.)
The Song that follows the Signs here, has pretty bits and good words in it.

LG.L: SEint Ieremie telleþ in his book; of xv. tokenyng
Þat god wil aȝeins domesdai; here on erþe bring:
Þe first day þe Cee schal arise; & as a wal stonde,
Wel heiȝer by .xl feet; þan any hil in þis londe.
Þat oþer dai, it schal so lowe aliȝt; þat vnneþe men schul it se;
Alle þe fissches þe þrid day; abouen þe water schull be,
& so reuly a cri ȝiuen; þat all men schullen haue fere;
Þe fierþe day, water schal brenne; as þeiȝ it coles were;
Þe vte. day, schal euerych tre; blede dropes of blood;
Þe vjte. day, schull castels & houses fall; all þat euer stood;
Þe vijte. day, stones schull fiȝtt; þe viij. þe erþe quake;
Þe ixe day, all hilles spreden abrod; & al þe werld euen make;
Þe x. day, men schul renne aboute; as þai wode were,
As wilde bestes holes to seche; to hide hem inne for fere.
// Þe xj. day, bones of ded men; arisen schull & vpriȝt stonde;
Þe xij dai, as þeiȝ it steren weren; fram heuen to þe londe;
Þe xiij. dai, vche quik þing schal dye; þe xiiij. fire aliȝt,
And brenne al þe middelerd; so crist it wil diȝt;
Þe xv. dai, schollen .iiij. Aungels comen; a .iiij. half mydlerde,
& blowen þorouȝ-out al þe werlde; þat vche man schal be aferd;
ffor in þilk age he schal arise; þat god was inne ded,
Of litel more þan .xxxti. wyntren; as ich ȝou habbe ised,

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Lamentacio animarum.[This is the Head line in the MS, tho' there is no break in the story.]

LG.L: Wiþ þilk body þat he had here; he ne schal so litel misse
As þe lest her of his body; I sigge ȝou Iwisse.
Oure lord schal come & smyte adoun; as liȝttyng doþ to ground,
Þere þat he to heuen stiȝe; with his bledyng wounde.MS. woudē
An Aungel schal þe spere & þe nails; & þe crovne of þorn,
& þe rood þat he died on; with hym bringe aforn.
In þe vale of Iosephat; his dom he wil do;
Þe best man schal sore agrise; þat schal come þerto.
Leuere had his owen moder; in helle pyne to be,
Al þe while þe dom ylast; þan her sones face to see.
Allas! hou schull we þan ouercome; þilk griselich fere,
Whan vche seint schal aferde be; oure lord crist to see þere?
OVre lord wil schewe his bitter woundes; And Sigge, "Man! for þe,
Look what ich haue ysuffred; what hastow suffred for me?"
Mest he wil vnderstonde þere; þe vij. merciful dedes:
Who þat haþ hem here ydo; as he with his mouþ sede,
Þe hungri forto fede; & schride þe cloþles,
Ofte goo to sek men; & herberewe þe housles,
Þe dede forto bury,; þe bounden to vnbynde,
Þai þat þise on erþe loueden; þere hij schullen it fynde.
OVre lord wil to þe liþer sigge; as we reden in gospelle,
"ȝe cursed gostes, goþ; in-to þe pyne of helle!"
Þe deuelen willen come ȝernend; & speten fire & blast,
& taken þe wrecched soulen; & in-to pyne hem cast.
OVre lord wil to good men sigge; "in my riȝth honde ȝe come,
And afongeþ my fador riche; þat aȝeins ȝow is ynome,
Þat to ȝou was ymaked; bifore þe werldes biginnyng;
Þere ȝe schullen be in ioye with me; wiþ-outen any endyng."
In þis book we finde ywrite; þat þre manere folk schal saued be,
Maidenhod & spousehod; & widewehode: þise þre.
Ich bid hym þat vs deme schal; kyng of all kynge,
Among his blissed sones; oure soules to heuen brynge. Amen.
Off ioye & blisse is my song; care to bileue,
& to herie hym among; þat al oure sorouȝ schal reue.
Ycome he is, þat swete dew; þat swete hony drope,
Iesus, kynge of alle kynges; to whom is al oure hope.
Bicome he is oure broþer; whare was he so longe;
He it is, & non oþer; þat bouȝth vs so stronge.
Oure broþer we mowe hym clepe wel; so seiþ hym-self ilome,
& so ne miȝtten þai neuer adel; þat bifore vs come.
He nas oure broþer nouȝth; er he oure flesch nome;
Þerwiþ he haþ vs dere abouȝth; to maken vs ysome.
ysome nere we nouȝth bifore; Aungels & oure kynde,
Er swete Iesus were ybore; þat to selde is in mynde.
// Bot now he haþ oure flesch ynome; & oure broþer is;
Oure kynde is wel heiȝe ycome; among oþer, Iwis;
ffor he is oure kynde heixt; saue his godhede,
& al aboue his throne next; so heiȝe is manhede.
Aungel ne worþ hym nouȝt so neiȝ; for he is oure broþer nouȝth,
& þat oure kynde is ek so heiȝe; he haþ vs dere abouȝth.
Aungels he ne bouȝth nouȝth; we ben hym wel neer;
Whan he haþ vs so dere bouȝth; wel ouȝtten we to louen hym here.
Ne aungel nys naþemo; bot his messagere,
How miȝth it þan go; to be his broþer here?
& in heuen þai schullen also; whan þat we ben þere,
Oure hestes & oure will do; as þai oure hynen were,
And to oure heste seruen vs; to foot & to honde,
Oure owen mowe we holden hem; as ich vnderstonde;
wel mowe we þan glade be; to habbe suich an hyne.
& siþþe we mowe here isee; as we iseþ atte fyne,
Þat we ben alþer kynde heiȝest; wiþ-oute god al-one,
And in heuen also hym next; among his aungels vchone.
And all þat now late comen; siþ oure lorde aliȝth,
And oure flesch haþ here ynomen; yheried be his miȝth!
Þilk þat toforne vs come; whan þai þe deþ founde,
Þan were þai onon ycast; in-to helle grounde.
Nere he neuer so holy ne so good; þere nas non forbore;
And so hem longed sore; after oure lorde þerfore.
// Þe prophetes þat weren so good; & so holy alle,
Þat of oure lorde vnderstoden; & what schulde bi-fall,
Hij wisten þat he schulde come; ac hij nysten whanne;
Þe tyme hem þouȝt long ynouȝ; vche ynche hem þouȝt a spanne.
Þai gradden after hym oft; in her prophecie,
And in þe bokes þat þai writen; þat he schulde dye:
"God ȝeue," quoþ on of hem; "þat heuen broste atwo,
Þat he miȝth aliȝth adoun; & vs sauen so."
Sumdel hem longed þo; whan þai nolden abide,
Þat heuen cleue soft a two; to saue vche side.
Ac it schulde al to brest; & oure lorde falle adoune,
Miȝth þai hym haue yhent; fast by þe crovne.
Ac he ne heiȝed nouȝth so swiþ; bot com soft adoun;
Þai wolde hym narewȝ hab y-hent; ac he held hem þer doun.
Parde, ȝit ne com he nouȝth; ne were hem neuer so wo;
Þai hadden þe grounde of helle isouȝth; er he com hem to.
Seint Dauid after his anoie; after hym grad þus:
"Lord, in heuen to vs abowȝe; & aliȝth to vs!
Schewe vs þine holy face; & we worþe hool onon."
Hym longed ek after his face; þe holy Symeon,
And all blis hym was bynome; & oft he gradd þerfore:
"Lorde, whan wiltou come; & wilt ben ybore?
Wene ȝe ich may dure; wene ȝe ich may see?"
Her mone was doel to see; þere gamed hem no gle.
// Ac hym ne greued nouȝth; aȝeins oþer bifore,
ffor he nas nouȝth to deþ ibrouȝth; er god were ibore,
Ac liued forto he hym seiȝ; & in his armes nome,
Þo he on Candelmesday; to þe temple come.
Lorde, wel may vs be; bet þan hem was þo,
Þat ne miȝtten nower fle; lorde, what hem was wo.
Þere oure lorde seide; þo he was ybore,
Þat we miȝtten ben ful glade; ouer oþer þat weren bifore.
Þe prophetes wilned hym forto see; & many kynges also,
Þat we isen ȝif it miȝth be; ac hij ne miȝtten it nouȝth do.
// we mowen now as it were; for nouȝth, to heuen come,
Siþþen oure lord it had ibouȝth; & þe fendes power bynome.
Ac þai þat suich grace ne hadden; þat tofore vs come,
After oure lorde þai gradden; in þe prophecie ylome;
After hym þai gradden; wiþ gret wille & longe;
No mendement þai ne seie; bot gret pyne & stronge;
So longe þat þai wery weren; & leten be al stille,
And he[r] gredyng forberen; & turneden to goddes wille;
ffor þai ne seiȝen non oþer won; þouȝ hem þouȝtten longe;
Oure lorde lete her will ago; er he wolde flesch a-fonge.
And þo þai weren wery ynouȝ; as who seiþ for sore,
Vche of hem to rest drouȝ; & speken of hym nomore,
Þat swete barne oure kynde took; boþe of flesche & felle,
In whiche he dyed on rood; þe fendes strengþe to felle.
Þorouȝ whiche preciouse deþ; god vs grant þat grace
Þat we mowe after oure deþ; in heuen haue a place. Amen.

DIV1.HEAD: SOLOMON'S CORONATION, DEEDS, AND JUDGMENT ON THE TWO MOTHERS' CLAIM TO ONE CHILD. HIS COURT AND TEMPLE.

ARGUMENT.P: [In order to complete the Life of Solomon, of which his Book of Wisdom, &c., form part, I add the MS. bit that comes before the Book. The passage about his birth is too far back to be taken.]

LG.L: ¶ Þo Dauid in elde was; his eldest son was alyue.
Adonye ycleped he was; with Salamon he gan striue.
Aboute he was kyng to be; by his fader daye.
Gret feste he made on a day; þat folk to paye.
He ne bad nowgth þider Salamon; ne his moder þe quene;
Þerfore sche was with hym wroþ; for wymmen beþ oft kene.
"Sir," sche seide to Dauid; "oft þou swore me,
Þat my son Salamon; schulde be kyng after þe.
Now haþ Adonye iþouȝth to be kyng bi þi lyue;
& after þi day to sle my son; for þai ne ben by on wyue."
ÞE kyng lete somony all his men: a fest he made sone,
And lete coroone Salamon; & sette hym in his throne.
By his lyue he made hym kyng; & bigan to prechi fast
fforto sustene vp goddes lawȝe; þer-while his lif ylast;
Þat he bulde forþ goddes hous in Ierusalems burghȝ,
Þat þe lawȝes better weren; ysustened þorouȝ & þorouȝ.
Dauid was kyng fourty wyntren; in werre & in strife;
And in þe fourtide ȝer; in pes he ended his lyf.
Afftere his fader, Salamon; slouȝ his broþer Adonye
In þe first ȝer, & all þat with hym weren; to hym he made boweye,
& he wex faiþful man & wis; þat folk better to wisse,
Þe kynges douȝttere of Egipte; he wedded in gret blisse.
Þe grete þinges forto don; he destred[? desired] goddes grace,
fforto arere goddes temple; in on faire place,

Þat to his bihofþe & vche riche kyng; þe court arered were,
His sacrifise he dude to god; & gan to hym crie:
"Lorde!" he seide, "to ȝong icham; to haue suich maistrie.
Teche me, ȝif þi wille be; wel my folk to wisse,
And to knowe god & yuel; þat I þerof ne mysse."
Oure lord hym graunted þinges þre; to haue maistri ouer his fo,
To habbe worldes richesse ynouȝ; & wisdom ynouȝ þerto.
IT bifel þat two wymmen; in on In, a niȝth were;
Eiþer had a ȝong childe; boþe of on ȝere.
In hire slep þat o womman; her owen childe ouerlay,
And siþþe leide it by her felawe; & hir child nom away.
Þo þe womman awook; & vnderȝat þis gile,
Ȝerne þai striueden & chid · for þe quik child a long while.
Þat on seide, þe quyk childe was hire; þat oþer seide it nas.
Boþe þei comen bifore þe kyng; & tolden al her cas.
¶ Þo þe kyng ne miȝth vnderȝete; wheþer had þe riȝth,
"Take hider," he seide, "my swerd; & euen, I wil it diȝth;
Cleuen ich wil, ȝif ich can; þe quyk childe a two.
& taken eiþer of ȝou þe haluendel; whan ȝe nyllen oþer do."
"Ȝe, sir," seide þe fals quene; "crist it ȝelde þe;
So þou miȝth best legge strif; þan mowe we euen be."
"Nay, sir," seide þe riȝth moder; "mercy, þat do þou nouȝth!
Take hire raþer euerich del; þat it ne be to deþ ybrouȝth."
"Ȝe, good womman," þe kyng seide; "take þat child to þe;
ffor þou hast þe riȝth weye; & þe oþere þe falste."

Good pais þere was in hil londe; þer while he kyng was.
